Although this analysis is (more or less) correct from a purely phonetic point of view, it hides the diachronic nature of Burmese vowel development and mergers, and obfuscates the reasoning behind Burmese orthography. ====Vowels in open syllables==== Synchronically, there can be said to be a total of 10 vowels in Modern Standard Burmese (MSB) open syllables: /a/ /uÃØa/ /…õ/ /uÃØ…õ/ /e/ /uÃØe/ /i/ /…î/ /o/ /u/. This may explain why the Burmese orthography indicates the vowel /o/ with both the diacritics for both the /i/ and /u/ vowels and, previously, a following consonantal /w/. ====Finals==== MSB recognises 8 finals in native vocabulary which are all distinguished from their initial forms with the c-shaped superscript diacritic ''asat'' ( ·Ä∫ ) which for ease of reading, is omitted here: the stops: ·Äï /p/ ·Äê /t/ ·ÄÖ /c/Note that ( ·ÄÖ ), here labeled ‚Äúpalatal‚Äù and transcribed as ''-c'' is pronounced /s/ initially in MSB but it is attested as an affricate /ts/ as recently as the 1800's and in earlier stages was likely /t É~t…ï/ and before that /c/, mimicking the development of Latin ‚ü®C‚ü© in the daughter Romance languages / k > c > t É (> ts > s (> Œ∏)) /. ·ÄÄ /k/ and the nasals: ·Äô /m/ ·Äî /n/ ·Ää / ·Äâ /…≤/( ·Ää )and ( ·Äâ ) behave much the same, except that ( ·Ää ) is not itself pronounced, and has a broader range of effects on the vowel. However, in MSB, */…π/, for which there is also a unique initial letter ( ·Äõ ), is pronounced /j/ in all instances (usually realised as [ ù] initially) except in loan words. The letter for /l/ ( ·Äú ) is still pronounced as /l/ in initial position, but as a medial, it has completely merged with /-j-/ and /-…π-/. In OB inscriptions this medial could be rendered with a subscript or ‚Äústacked‚Äù ·Äú as in ( ·ÄÄ·Äπ·Äú ), a practice still used in the rare dialects, such as Tavoyan/Dawe where the /-l-/ medial is still pronounced distinctly. These medials behave differently than the /uÃØ/ onglide in the following ways: * a medial */-j-/ */-l-/ */-…π-/ can be placed before the on-glide /uÃØ/, whereas two medials can never be used in the same syllable. * the use of /uÃØ/ is restricted by the vowel nucleus (only used with /a/ /…õ/ /e/) and may in some cases drastically change the pronunciation of the vowel e.g. in Yangon /wa/ before a final becomes [u], while /a/ before a final becomes [√¶]. However, it cannot affect the pronunciation of the initial. * glides are restricted by the preceding initial, and often change its pronunciation. Bearing in mind that MSB does not reliably indicate the development of */-l-/, /m/ /p ∞/ /p/ /b/ can apparently be followed by any glide, in which case the glide becomes [ ≤]. Similarly /k ∞/ /k/ and /g/ can be followed by any glide, in which case the cluster becomes [t…ï ∞] [t…ï] or [d ë] respectively. /≈ã/ can be followed by /-…π-/ but not /-j-/ in which case the cluster becomes […≤], merging with the palatal nasal letter ( ·Ää / ·Äâ ). And finally, /l/ can be followed by /-j-/ but not /-…π-/. It should be noted that this is rare and in Yangon MSB this represents the only case where the medial impacts the vowel, whereby the sequence ·Äú·Äª·Ä¨ */ljaÀê/ is realised [leaÃØ]. Tavoyan front vowels are frequently raised following /-j-/. There is, at least in Yangon MSB, no difference between an initial /j/ /…π/ /w/ and a null initial with /-j-/ /-…π-/ /uÃØ/. This extends to a /w/ initial followed by a /uÃØ/ onglide. Therefore, in Yangon (and likely much of MSB) /wa/, /√òuÃØa/, and /wuÃØa/ are pronounced identically. === Tones === Burmese is a [[tonal language]], which means [[phoneme|phonemic]] contrasts can be made on the basis of the [[tone (linguistics)|tone]] of a vowel. In Burmese, these contrasts involve not only [[pitch (music)|pitch]], but also [[phonation]], intensity (loudness), duration, and vowel quality. However, some linguists consider Burmese a [[Register (phonology)|pitch-register language]] like [[Shanghainese]].{{sfn|Jones|1986|p=135-136}} There are four contrastive tones in Burmese. Linguist L. F. Taylor concluded that "conversational rhythm and euphonic intonation possess importance" not found in related tonal languages and that "its tonal system is now in an advanced state of decay."{{sfn|Taylor|1920}}{{sfn|Benedict|1948|p=184‚Äì191}} === Syllable structure === The [[syllable]] structure of Burmese is C(G)V((V)C), which is to say the [[syllable onset|onset]] consists of a consonant optionally followed by a [[semivowel|glide]], and the [[syllable rime|rime]] consists of a monophthong alone, a monophthong with a consonant, or a diphthong with a consonant. The only consonants that can stand in the [[syllable coda|coda]] are {{IPA|/ î/}} and {{IPA|/…¥/}}. Some representative words are: * CV {{IPA|/m√®/}} 'girl' * CVC {{IPA|/m…õ î/}} 'crave' * CGV {{IPA|/mj√®/}} 'earth' * CGVC {{IPA|/mj…õ î/}} 'eye' * CVVC {{IPA|/m√† ä…¥/}} (term of address for young men) * CGVVC {{IPA|/mj√° ä…¥/}} 'ditch' A [[minor syllable]] has some restrictions: * It contains {{IPA|/…ô/}} as its only vowel * It must be an open syllable (no coda consonant) * It cannot bear tone * It has only a simple (C) onset (no glide after the consonant) * It must not be the final syllable of the word Some examples of words containing minor syllables: * {{IPA|/k ∞…ô.lo ä î/}} 'knob' * {{IPA|/p…ô.lw√®/}} 'flute' * {{IPA|/Œ∏…ô.j…îÃÄ/}} 'mock' * {{IPA|/k…ô.l…õ î/}} 'be wanton' * {{IPA|/t ∞…ô.m…ô.j√®/}} 'rice-water' == Alphabet == {{Main|Burmese alphabet}} [[File:Vendeurs de plantes m√©dicinales vers Kyaiktiyo Paya.jpg|thumb|Sampling of various Burmese script styles]] The Burmese alphabet consists of 33 letters and 12 vowels, and is written from left to right. It requires no spaces between words, although modern writing usually contains spaces after each clause to enhance readability. Characterized by its circular letters and diacritics, the script is an [[abugida]], with all letters having an inherent vowel {{lang|my|·Ä°}} ''a.'' {{IPA-my|aÃ∞|}} or {{IPA-my|…ô|}}. The consonants are arranged into [[Burmese alphabet#Arrangement|six consonant groups]] (called {{lang|my|·Äù·ÄÇ·Ä∫}} based on articulation, like other Brahmi scripts. Tone markings and vowel modifications are written as diacritics placed to the left, right, top, and bottom of letters.{{sfn|Herbert|Milner|1989}} The development of the script followed that of the language, which is generally divided into Old Burmese, Middle Burmese and modern Burmese. Old Burmese dates from the 11th to the 16th century ([[Pagan Kingdom|Pagan]] and [[Ava Kingdom|Ava]] dynasties); Middle Burmese from the 16th to the 18th century ([[Taungoo Dynasty|Toungoo]] to early [[Konbaung Dynasty|Konbaung]] dynasties); modern Burmese from the mid-18th century to the present. Orthographic changes followed shifts in phonology (such as the merging of the {{IPA|[-l-]}} and {{IPA|[-…π-]}} medials) rather than transformations in Burmese grammatical structure and phonology, which has not changed much from Old Burmese to modern Burmese.{{sfn|Herbert|Milner|1989}} For example, during the Pagan era, the medial {{IPA|[-l-]}} {{lang|my|·Äπ·Äú}} was transcribed in writing, which has been replaced by medials {{IPA|[-j-]}} {{lang|my|·Äª}} and {{IPA|[-…π-]}} {{lang|my|·Äº}} in modern Burmese (e.g. "school" in old Burmese {{lang|my|·ÄÄ·Äπ·Äú·Ä±·Ä¨·ÄÑ·Ä∫}} {{IPA-my|kl…î≈ã|}} ‚Üí {{lang|my|·ÄÄ·Äª·Ä±·Ä¨·ÄÑ·Ä∫·Ä∏}} {{IPA-my|t…ï√° ä…¥|}} in modern Burmese).{{sfn|Khin Min|1987}} Likewise written Burmese has preserved all nasalized finals {{IPA|[-n, -m, -≈ã]}}, which have merged to {{IPA|[-…¥]}} in spoken Burmese. (The exception is {{IPA|[-…≤]}}, which, in spoken Burmese, can be one of many open vowels {{IPA|[i, e, …õ]}}. Likewise, other consonantal finals {{IPA|[-s, -p, -t, -k]}} have been reduced to {{IPA|[- î]}}. Similar mergers are seen in other Sino-Tibetan languages like [[Shanghainese#Rimes|Shanghainese]], and to a lesser extent, [[Standard Cantonese#Current Shifts|Cantonese]].) Written Burmese dates to the [[Pagan Kingdom#Early Pagan|early Pagan period]]. The [[British rule in Burma|British colonial period]] scholars believed that the Burmese script was developed c. 1058 from the [[Mon script]].{{sfn|Harvey|1925|p=307}} However, evidence shows that the Burmese script has been in use at least since 1035 (perhaps as early as 984) while the earliest Burma Mon script, which is different from the Thailand Mon script, dates to 1093.{{sfn|Aung-Thwin|2005|p=167‚Äì178, 197‚Äì200}} The Burmese script may have been sourced from the [[Pyu script]].{{sfn|Aung-Thwin|2005|p=167‚Äì178, 197‚Äì200}} (Both Mon and Pyu scripts are derivatives of the [[Brahmi script]].) Burmese orthography originally followed a square format but the cursive format took hold from the 17th century when popular writing led to the wider use of palm leaves and folded paper known as ''parabaiks'' {{lang|my|·Äï·ÄØ·Äõ·Äï·Ä≠·ÄØ·ÄÄ·Ä∫}}.{{sfn|Lieberman|2003|p=136}} Much of the orthography in written Burmese today can be traced back to Middle Burmese. Standardized tone marking was not achieved until the 18th century. From the 19th century onward, orthographers created spellers to reform Burmese spelling, because ambiguities arose over spelling sounds that had been merged.{{sfn|Herbert|Milner|1989}} During British colonial rule, Burmese spelling was standardized through dictionaries and spellers. The latest spelling authority, named the ''Myanma Salonpaung Thatpon Kyan'' {{lang|my|·Äô·Äº·Äî·Ä∫·Äô·Ä¨ ·ÄÖ·Ä¨·Äú·ÄØ·Ä∂·Ä∏·Äï·Ä±·Ä´·ÄÑ·Ä∫·Ä∏ ·Äû·Äê·Ä∫·Äï·ÄØ·Ä∂ ·ÄÄ·Äª·Äô·Ä∫·Ä∏}}, was compiled in 1978 at the request of the Burmese government.{{sfn|Herbert|Milner|1989}} == Grammar == The basic [[word order]] of the Burmese language is [[subject (grammar)|subject]]-[[object (grammar)|object]]-[[verb]]. Pronouns in Burmese vary according to the gender and status of the audience. Burmese is [[monosyllabic]] (i.e., every word is a root to which a particle but not another word may be prefixed).{{sfn|Taw Sein Ko|1924|p=viii}} Sentence structure determines syntactical relations and verbs are not conjugated. Instead they have particles suffixed to them. For example, the verb "to eat," {{lang|my|·ÄÖ·Ä¨·Ä∏}} ''ca:'' {{IPA-my|s√†|}} is itself unchanged when modified. === Adjectives === Burmese does not have [[adjective]]s per se. Rather, it has verbs that carry the meaning "to be X", where X is an English adjective. These verbs can modify a noun by means of the grammatical particle {{lang|my|·Äê·Ä≤·Ä∑}} ''tai.'' {{IPA-my|d…õÃ∞|}} in colloquial Burmese (literary form: {{lang|my|·Äû·Ä±·Ä¨}} ''sau:'' {{IPA-my|Œ∏…îÃÅ|}}, which is suffixed as follows: :Colloquial: {{lang|my|·ÄÅ·Äª·Ä±·Ä¨·Äê·Ä≤·Ä∑·Äú·Ä∞}} ''hkyau: tai. lu'' {{IPA-my|t…ï ∞…îÃÅ d…õÃ∞ l√π|}} :Formal: {{lang|my|·ÄÅ·Äª·Ä±·Ä¨·Äû·Ä±·Ä¨·Äú·Ä∞}} ''hkyau: so: lu'' :Gloss: "beautiful" + adjective particle + "person" Adjectives may also form a [[compound (linguistics)|compound]] with the noun (e.g. {{lang|my|·Äú·Ä∞·ÄÅ·Äª·Ä±·Ä¨}} ''lu hkyau:'' {{IPA-my|l√π t…ï ∞…îÃÅ|}} "person" + "be beautiful"). [[Comparative]]s are usually ordered: X + {{lang|my|·Äë·ÄÄ·Ä∫·Äï·Ä≠·ÄØ}} ''htak pui'' {{IPA-my|t ∞e î p√≤|}} + adjective, where X is the object being compared to. [[Superlative]]s are indicated with the prefix {{lang|my|·Ä°}} ''a.'' {{IPA-my| î…ô|}} + adjective + {{lang|my|·ÄÜ·ÄØ·Ä∂·Ä∏}} ''hcum:'' {{IPA-my|z√≥ ä…¥|}}. Numerals follow the nouns they modify. Moreover, numerals follow several pronunciation rules that involve tone changes (low tone ‚Üí creaky tone) and voicing shifts depending on the pronunciation of surrounding words. A more thorough explanation is found on [[Burmese numerals]]. === Verbs === The roots of Burmese [[verbs]] are almost always suffixed with at least one particle which conveys such information as tense, intention, politeness, mood, etc. Many of these particles also have formal/literary and colloquial equivalents. In fact, the only time in which no particle is attached to a verb is in imperative commands. The most commonly used verb particles and their usage are shown below with an example verb root {{lang|my|·ÄÖ·Ä¨·Ä∏}} ''ca:'' {{IPA-my|s√°|}} "to eat". Alone, the statement {{lang|my|·ÄÖ·Ä¨·Ä∏}} is imperative. The suffix {{lang|my|·Äê·Äö·Ä∫}} ''tai'' {{IPA-my|d…õÃÄ|}} (literary form: {{lang|my|·Äû·Ää·Ä∫}} ''sany'' {{IPA-my|√∞√¨|}} can be viewed as a particle marking the present tense and/or a factual statement: :{{lang|my|·ÄÖ·Ä¨·Ä∏·Äê·Äö·Ä∫}} ''ca: tai'' {{IPA-my|s√° d…õÃÄ|}} "I eat" The suffix {{lang|my|·ÄÅ·Ä≤·Ä∑}} ''hkai.'' {{IPA-my|…°…õÃ∞|}} denotes that the action took place in the past. However, this particle is not always necessary to indicate the past tense such that it can convey the same information without it. But to emphasize that the action happened before another event that is also currently being discussed, the particle becomes imperative. Note that the suffix {{lang|my|·Äê·Äö·Ä∫}} ''tai'' {{IPA-my|d…õÃÄ|}} in this case denotes a factual statement rather than the present tense: :{{lang|my|·ÄÖ·Ä¨·Ä∏·ÄÅ·Ä≤·Ä∑·Äê·Äö·Ä∫}} ''ca: hkai. tai'' {{IPA-my|s√° …°…õÃ∞ d…õÃÄ|}} "I ate" The particle {{lang|my|·Äî·Ä±}} ''ne'' {{IPA-my|n√®|}} is used to denote an action in progression. It is equivalent to the English '-ing'" :{{lang|my|·ÄÖ·Ä¨·Ä∏·Äî·Ä±·Äê·Äö·Ä∫}} ''ca: ne tai'' {{IPA-my|s√° n√® d…õÃÄ|}} "I am eating" This particle {{lang|my|·Äï·Äº·ÄÆ}} ''pri'' {{IPA-my|bj√¨|}}, which is used when an action that had been expected to be performed by the subject is now finally being performed, has no equivalent in English. So in the above example, if someone had been expecting you to eat and you have finally started eating, the particle {{lang|my|·Äï·Äº·ÄÆ}} is used as follows: :{{lang|my|(·ÄÖ)·ÄÖ·Ä¨·Ä∏·Äï·Äº·ÄÆ}} ''(ca.) ca: pri'' {{IPA-my|(s…ô) s√° bj√¨|}} "I am (now) eating" The particle {{lang|my|·Äô·Äö·Ä∫}} ''mai'' {{IPA-my|m…õÃÄ|}} (literary form: {{lang|my|·Äô·Ää·Ä∫}} ''many'' {{IPA-my|mj√¨|}} is used to indicate the future tense or an action which is yet to be performed: :{{lang|my|·ÄÖ·Ä¨·Ä∏·Äô·Äö·Ä∫}} ''ca: mai'' {{IPA-my|s√° m…õÃÄ|}} "I will eat" The particle {{lang|my|·Äê·Ä±·Ä¨·Ä∑}} ''tau.'' {{IPA-my|d…îÃ∞|}} is used when the action is about to be performed immediately when used in conjunction with {{lang|my|·Äô·Äö·Ä∫}}. Therefore it could be termed as the "immediate future tense particle". :{{lang|my|·ÄÖ·Ä¨·Ä∏·Äê·Ä±·Ä¨·Ä∑·Äô·Äö·Ä∫}} ''ca: tau. mai'' {{IPA-my|s√° d…îÃ∞ m…õÃÄ|}} "I'm going to eat (straight-away)" When {{lang|my|·Äê·Ä±·Ä¨·Ä∑}} is used alone, however, it is imperative: :{{lang|my|·ÄÖ·Ä¨·Ä∏·Äê·Ä±·Ä¨·Ä∑}} ''ca: tau.'' {{IPA-my|s√° d…îÃ∞|}} "Eat (now)" Verbs are negated by the particle {{lang|my|·Äô}} ''ma.'' {{IPA-my|m…ô|}}, which is prefixed to the verb. Generally speaking, other particles are suffixed to that verb, along with {{lang|my|·Äô}}. The verb suffix particle {{lang|my|·Äî·Ä≤·Ä∑}} ''nai.'' {{IPA-my|n…õÃ∞|}} (literary form: {{lang|my|·Äî·Äæ·ÄÑ·Ä∑·Ä∫}} ''hnang.'' {{IPA-my|nÃ•…™Ã∞…¥|}} indicates a command: :{{lang|my|·Äô·ÄÖ·Ä¨·Ä∏·Äî·Ä≤·Ä∑}} ''ma.ca: nai.'' {{IPA-my|m…ôs√° n…õÃ∞|}} Don't eat The verb suffix particle {{lang|my|·Äò·Ä∞·Ä∏}} ''bhu:'' {{IPA-my|b√∫|}} indicates a statement: :{{lang|my|·Äô·ÄÖ·Ä¨·Ä∏·Äò·Ä∞·Ä∏}} ''ma.ca: bhu:'' {{IPA-my|m…ôs√° b√∫|}} "[I] don't eat" === Nouns === [[Noun]]s in Burmese are pluralized by suffixing the particle {{lang|my|·Äê·ÄΩ·Ä±}} ''twe'' {{IPA-my|d√®|}} (or {{IPA-my|t√®|}} if the word ends in a glottal stop) in colloquial Burmese or {{lang|my|·Äô·Äª·Ä¨·Ä∏}} ''mya:'' {{IPA-my|mj√†|}} in formal Burmese. The particle {{lang|my|·Äê·Ä≠·ÄØ·Ä∑}} (tou. {{IPA-my|toÃ∞|}}, which indicates a group of persons or things, is also suffixed to the modified noun. An example is below: * {{lang|my|·Äô·Äº·ÄÖ·Ä∫}} ''mrac'' {{IPA-my|mj…™ î|}} "river" * {{lang|my|·Äô·Äº·ÄÖ·Ä∫·Äê·ÄΩ·Ä±}} ''mrac twe'' {{IPA-my|mj…™ î t√®|}} "rivers" (colloquial) * {{lang|my|·Äô·Äº·ÄÖ·Ä∫·Äô·Äª·Ä¨·Ä∏}} ''mrac mya:'' {{IPA-my|mj…™ î mj√°|}} "rivers" (formal) * {{lang|my|·Äô·Äº·ÄÖ·Ä∫·Äê·Ä≠·ÄØ·Ä∑}} ''mrac tou:'' {{IPA-my|mj…™ î toÃ∞|}} "rivers" Plural suffixes are not used when the noun is quantified with a number. :{| |+"five children" |- | {{lang|my|·ÄÄ·Äú·Ä±·Ä∏}} || {{lang|my|·ÅÖ}} || {{lang|my|·Äö·Ä±·Ä¨·ÄÄ·Ä∫}} |- | ''hka.le:'' || ''nga:'' || ''yauk'' |- | {{IPA|/k ∞…ôl√©}} || {{IPA|≈ã√°}} || {{IPA|ja ä î/}} |- | child || five || classifier |- |} Although Burmese does not have grammatical gender (e.g. masculine or feminine nouns), a distinction is made between the sexes, especially in animals and plants, by means of suffix particles. Nouns are masculinized with the following particles: {{lang|my|·Äë·ÄÆ·Ä∏}} ''hti:'' {{IPA-my|t ∞√≠|}}, {{lang|my|·Äñ}} ''hpa'' {{IPA-my|p ∞aÃ∞|}}, or {{lang|my|·Äñ·Ä≠·ÄØ}} ''hpui'' {{IPA-my|p ∞√≤|}}, depending on the noun, and feminized with the particle {{lang|my|·Äô}} ''ma.'' {{IPA-my|maÃ∞|}}. Examples of usage are below: * {{lang|my|·ÄÄ·Äº·Ä±·Ä¨·ÄÑ·Ä∫·Äë·ÄÆ·Ä∏}} ''kraung hti:'' {{IPA-my|t…ï√† ä…¥ t ∞√≠|}} "male cat" * {{lang|my|·ÄÄ·Äº·Ä±·Ä¨·ÄÑ·Ä∫·Äô}} ''kraung ma.'' {{IPA-my|t…ï√† ä…¥ maÃ∞|}} "female cat" * {{lang|my|·ÄÄ·Äº·ÄÄ·Ä∫·Äñ}} ''krak hpa.'' {{IPA-my|t…ï…õ î p ∞aÃ∞|}} "rooster/cock" * {{lang|my|·Äë·Äî·Ä∫·Ä∏·Äñ·Ä≠·ÄØ}} ''htan: hpui'' {{IPA-my|t ∞√°…¥ p ∞√≤|}} "male [[toddy palm]] plant" ==== Numerical classifiers ==== {{Main|Burmese numerical classifiers}} Like its neighboring languages such as [[Thai language|Thai]], [[Bengali language|Bengali]], and [[Chinese language|Chinese]], Burmese uses numerical classifiers (also called measure words) when nouns are counted or quantified. This approximately equates to English expressions such as "two slices of bread" or "a cup of coffee". Classifiers are required when counting nouns, so {{lang|my|·ÄÄ·Äú·Ä±·Ä∏ ·ÅÖ}} ''hka.le: nga:'' {{IPA-my|k ∞…ôl√© ≈ã√†|}} (lit. "child five") is ungrammatical, because the measure word for people {{lang|my|·Äö·Ä±·Ä¨·ÄÄ·Ä∫}} ''yauk'' {{IPA-my|ja ä î|}} needs to suffix the numeral. The standard word order of quantified words is: quantified noun + numeral adjective + classifier, except in [[round number]]s (numbers that end in zero), in which the word order is flipped, where the quantified noun precedes the classifier: quantified noun + classifier + numeral adjective. The only exception to this rule is the number 10, which follows the standard word order. Measurements of time, such as "hour," {{lang|my|·Äî·Ä¨·Äõ·ÄÆ}} "day," {{lang|my|·Äõ·ÄÄ·Ä∫}} or "month," {{lang|my|·Äú}} do not require classifiers. Remarks |- | {{lang|my|·Äö·Ä±·Ä¨·ÄÄ·Ä∫}} || yauk || {{IPA-my|ja ä î|}} || for people || Used in informal context |- | {{lang|my|·Ä¶·Ä∏}} || u: || {{IPA-my| î√∫|}} || for people || Used in formal context and also used for monks and nuns |- | {{lang|my|·Äï·Ä´·Ä∏}} || pa: || {{IPA-my|b√°|}} || for people || Used exclusively for monks and nuns of the Buddhist order |- | {{lang|my|·ÄÄ·Ä±·Ä¨·ÄÑ·Ä∫}} || kaung || {{IPA-my|k√† ä…¥|}} || for animals || |- | {{lang|my|·ÄÅ·ÄØ}} || hku. || {{IPA-my|k ∞·πµ|}} || general classifier || Used with almost all nouns except for animate objects |- | {{lang|my|·Äú·ÄØ·Ä∂·Ä∏}} || lum: || {{IPA-my|l√≥ ä…¥|}} || for round objects || |- | {{lang|my|·Äï·Äº·Ä¨·Ä∏}} || pra: || {{IPA-my|pj√°|}} || for flat objects || |- | {{lang|my|·ÄÖ·ÄØ}} || cu. || {{IPA-my|s·πµ|}} || for groups || Can be {{IPA-my|z·πµ|}}. |} === Particles === The Burmese language makes prominent usage of [[Grammatical particle|particles]] (called {{lang|my|·Äï·ÄÖ·Äπ·ÄÖ·Ää·Ä∫·Ä∏}} in Burmese), which are untranslatable words that are suffixed or prefixed to words to indicate level of respect, grammatical tense, or mood. According to the ''[[Myanmar‚ÄìEnglish Dictionary]]'' (1993), there are 449 particles in the Burmese language. For example, {{lang|my|·ÄÖ·Äô·Ä∫·Ä∏}} {{IPA-my|s√°…¥|}} is a grammatical particle used to indicate the imperative mood. While {{lang|my|·Äú·ÄØ·Äï·Ä∫·Äï·Ä´}} ("work" + particle indicating politeness) does not indicate the imperative, {{lang|my|·Äú·ÄØ·Äï·Ä∫·ÄÖ·Äô·Ä∫·Ä∏·Äï·Ä´}} ("work" + particle indicating imperative mood + particle indicating politeness) does. Particles may be combined in some cases, especially those modifying verbs. Some particles modify the word's [[part of speech]]. Among the most prominent of these is the particle {{lang|my|·Ä°}} {{IPA-my|…ô|}}, which is prefixed to verbs and adjectives to form nouns or adverbs. For instance, the word {{lang|my|·Äù·ÄÑ·Ä∫}} means "to enter," but combined with {{lang|my|·Ä°}}, it means "entrance" {{lang|my|·Ä°·Äù·ÄÑ·Ä∫}}. Also, in colloquial Burmese, there is a tendency to omit the second {{lang|my|·Ä°}} in words that follow the pattern {{lang|my|·Ä°}} + noun/adverb + {{lang|my|·Ä°}} + noun/adverb, like {{lang|my|·Ä°·ÄÜ·Ä±·Ä¨·ÄÄ·Ä∫·Ä°·Ä°·ÄØ·Ä∂}}, which is pronounced {{IPA-my|…ôs ∞a ä î √∫|}} and formally pronounced {{IPA-my|…ôs ∞a ä î …ô√≤ ä…¥|}}. === Pronouns === Subject [[pronoun]]s begin sentences, though the subject is generally omitted in the imperative forms and in conversation. Grammatically speaking, subject marker particles {{lang|my|·ÄÄ}} {{IPA-my|…°aÃ∞|}} in colloquial, {{lang|my|·Äû·Ää·Ä∫}} {{IPA-my|Œ∏√¨|}} in formal) must be attached to the subject pronoun, although they are also generally omitted in conversation. Object pronouns must have an object marker particle {{lang|my|·ÄÄ·Ä≠·ÄØ}} {{IPA-my|…°√≤|}} in colloquial, {{lang|my|·Ä°·Ä¨·Ä∏}} {{IPA-my|√°|}} in formal) attached immediately after the pronoun. Proper nouns are often substituted for pronouns. One's status in relation to the audience determines the pronouns used, with certain pronouns used for different audiences. Polite pronouns are used to address elders, teachers and strangers, through the use of feudal-era third person pronouns in lieu of first and second person pronouns. In a testament to the power of media, the Yangon-based speech is gaining currency even in Upper Burma. Upper Burmese-specific usage, while historically and technically accurate, is increasingly viewed as countrified speech, or at best regional speech. In fact, some usages are already considered strictly regional Upper Burmese speech, and are likely dying out. For example: {| class="wikitable" |- ! width="200"|Term ! width="200"|Upper Burmese ! width="200"|Standard Burmese |- | * Elder brother (to a male) * Elder brother (to a female) | * {{lang|my|·Äî·Ä±·Ä¨·ÄÑ·Ä∫}} {{IPA-my|n√† ä…¥|}} * {{lang|my|·ÄÄ·Ä≠·ÄØ}} {{IPA-my|k√≤|}} | * {{lang|my|·ÄÄ·Ä≠·ÄØ}} {{IPA-my|k√≤|}} |- | * Younger brother (to a male) * Younger brother (to a female) |colspan="2"| * {{lang|my|·Ää·ÄÆ}} {{IPA-my|…≤√¨|}} * {{lang|my|·Äô·Ä±·Ä¨·ÄÑ·Ä∫}} {{IPA-my|m√† ä…¥|}} |- | * Elder sister (to a male) * Elder sister (to a female) |colspan="2"| * {{lang|my|·Äô}} {{IPA-my|maÃ∞|}} |- | * Younger sister (to a male) * Younger sister (to a female) | * {{lang|my|·Äî·Äæ·Äô}} {{IPA-my|…≤…ômaÃ∞|}} * {{lang|my|·Ää·ÄÆ·Äô}} {{IPA-my|…≤√¨ maÃ∞|}} | * {{lang|my|·Ää·ÄÆ·Äô}} {{IPA-my|…≤√¨ maÃ∞|}} |} In general, the male-centric names of old Burmese for familial terms have been replaced in standard Burmese with formerly female-centric terms, which are now used by both sexes. One holdover is the use of {{lang|my|·Ää·ÄÆ}} (younger brother to a male) and {{lang|my|·Äô·Ä±·Ä¨·ÄÑ·Ä∫}} (younger brother to a female). Terms like {{lang|my|·Äî·Ä±·Ä¨·ÄÑ·Ä∫}} (elder brother to a male) and {{lang|my|·Äî·Äæ·Äô}} (younger sister to a male) now are used in standard Burmese only as part of compound words like {{lang|my|·Ää·ÄÆ·Äî·Ä±·Ä¨·ÄÑ·Ä∫}} (brothers) or {{lang|my|·Äô·Ä±·Ä¨·ÄÑ·Ä∫·Äî·Äæ·Äô}} (brother and sister). === Reduplication === [[Reduplication]] is prevalent in Burmese and is used to intensify or weaken adjectives' meanings. For example, {{lang|my|·ÄÅ·Äª·Ä±·Ä¨}} {{IPA-my|t…ï ∞…îÃÅ|}} "beautiful" is reduplicated, the intensity of the adjective's meaning increases. Many Burmese words, especially adjectives with two syllables, such as {{lang|my|·Äú·Äæ·Äï}} {{IPA-my|lÃ•aÃ∞paÃ∞|}} "beautiful", when reduplicated ({{lang|my|·Äú·Äæ·Äï}} ‚Üí {{lang|my|·Äú·Äæ·Äú·Äæ·Äï·Äï}} {{IPA-my|lÃ•aÃ∞lÃ•aÃ∞ paÃ∞paÃ∞|}}) become [[adverb]]s. This is also true of some Burmese verbs and nouns (e.g. {{lang|my|·ÄÅ·Äè}} "a moment" ‚Üí {{lang|my|·ÄÅ·Äè·ÄÅ·Äè}} "frequently", which become adverbs when reduplicated. Some nouns are also reduplicated to indicate plurality. For instance, {{lang|my|·Äï·Äº·Ää·Ä∫}} {{IPA-my|pj√¨|}} "country", but when reduplicated to {{lang|my|·Ä°·Äï·Äº·Ää·Ä∫·Äï·Äº·Ää·Ä∫}} {{IPA-my|…ôpj√¨ pj√¨|}} "country", means "many countries," as in {{lang|my|·Ä°·Äï·Äº·Ää·Ä∫·Äï·Äº·Ää·Ä∫·ÄÜ·Ä≠·ÄØ·ÄÑ·Ä∫·Äõ·Ä¨}} {{IPA-my|…ôpj√¨ pj√¨ s ∞√†…™…¥ j√†|}} "international". Another example is {{lang|my|·Ä°·Äô·Äª·Ä≠·ÄØ·Ä∏}}, which means "a kind," but the reduplicated form {{lang|my|·Ä°·Äô·Äª·Ä≠·ÄØ·Ä∏·Äô·Äª·Ä≠·ÄØ·Ä∏}} means "multiple kinds." A few measure words can also be reduplicated to indicate "one or the other": * {{lang|my|·Äö·Ä±·Ä¨·ÄÄ·Ä∫}} (measure word for people) ‚Üí {{lang|my|·Äê·ÄÖ·Ä∫·Äö·Ä±·Ä¨·ÄÄ·Ä∫·Äö·Ä±·Ä¨·ÄÄ·Ä∫}} (someone) * {{lang|my|·ÄÅ·ÄØ}} (measure word for things) ‚Üí {{lang|my|·Äê·ÄÖ·Ä∫·ÄÅ·ÄØ·ÄÅ·ÄØ}} (something) == Romanization and transcription == {{Main|Romanization of Burmese}} There is no official [[romanization]] system for Burmese. There have been attempts to make one, but none have been successful. Replicating Burmese sounds in the Latin script is complicated. There is a Pali-based transcription system in existence, [[MLC Transcription System]] which was devised by the [[Myanmar Language Commission]] (MLC). However, it only transcribes sounds in formal Burmese and is based on the orthography rather than the phonology. Several colloquial transcription systems have been proposed, but none is overwhelmingly preferred over others. Transcription of Burmese is not standardized, as seen in the varying English transcriptions of Burmese names. For instance, a Burmese personal name like {{lang|my|·Äù·ÄÑ·Ä∫·Ä∏}} {{IPA-my|w…™ÃÅ…¥|}} may be variously romanized as Win, Winn, Wyn, or Wynn, while {{lang|my|·ÄÅ·Ä≠·ÄØ·ÄÑ·Ä∫}} {{IPA-my|k ∞√†…™…¥|}} may be romanized as Khaing, Khine, or Khain. == Computer fonts and standard keyboard layout == [[File:Myanmar-Keyboard-Layout.png|thumb|400px|Myanmar3, the ''de jure'' standard Burmese keyboard layout]] The Burmese script can be entered from a standard [[QWERTY keyboard]], and is supported within the Unicode standard, meaning it can be read and written from most modern computers and smartphones. Burmese has complex character rendering requirements, where tone markings and vowel modifications are noted using diacritics. These can be placed before consonants (as with {{lang|my|·Ä±}}), above them (as with {{lang|my|·Ä≠}}) or even around them (as with {{lang|my|·Äº}}). These character clusters are built using multiple keystrokes. In particular, the inconsistent placement of diacritics as a feature of the language presents a conflict between an intuitive [[WYSIWYG]] typing approach, and a logical consonant-first storage approach. Since its introduction in 2007, the most popular Burmese font, [[Zawgyi font|Zawgyi]], has been near-ubiquitous in Myanmar. Linguist Justin Watkins argues that the ubiquitous use of Zawgyi harms Myanmar languages, including Burmese, by preventing efficient sorting, searching, processing and analyzing Myanmar text through flexible diacritic ordering.{{Cite web|url=http://www.themimu.info/sites/themimu.info/files/documents/Presentation_Why_Stop_Zawgyi_Use_Unicode_Phandeeyar_Aug2016.pdf|title=Why we should stop Zawgyi in its tracks. It harms others and ourselves. Use Unicode!|last=Watkins|first=Justin|date=|website=|access-date=}} Zawgyi is not [[Unicode]]-compliant, but occupies the same code space as Unicode Myanmar font.{{Cite web|url=https://my.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Font|title=Myanmar Wikipedia ‚Äì Font|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}{{Better source|reason=per WP:CIRCULAR|date=November 2017}} As it is not defined as a standard character encoding, Zawgyi is not built in to any major operating systems as standard. However, allow for its position as the ''de facto'' (but largely undocumented) standard within the country, telcos and major smartphone distributors (such as Huawei and Samsung) ship phones with Zawgyi font overwriting standard Unicode-compliant fonts, which are installed on most internationally-distributed hardware.{{Cite web|url=http://frontiermyanmar.net/en/features/battle-of-the-fonts|title=Battle of the fonts|last=Hotchkiss|first=Griffin|date=23 March 2016|website=|access-date=}} Facebook also supports Zawgyi as an additional language encoding for their app and website.{{Cite web|url=http://blog.lwinmoe.org/2015/12/facebook-nods-to-zawgyi-and-unicode.html|title=Facebook nods to Zawgyi and Unicode|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}} As a result, almost all SMS alerts (including those from telcos to their customers), social media posts and other web resources may be incomprehensible on these devices without the custom Zawgyi font installed at the operating system level. These may include devices purchased overseas, or distributed by companies who do not customize software for the local market. Keyboards which have a Zawgyi keyboard layout printed on them are the most commonly available for purchase domestically. Until recently, Unicode compliant fonts have been more difficult to type than Zawgyi, as they have a stricter, less forgiving and arguably less intuitive method for ordering diacritics. However, intelligent input software such as Keymagic{{Cite web|url=https://keymagic.net/|title=Keymagic Unicode Keyboard Input Customizer|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}} and recent versions of smartphone soft-keyboards including [[Gboard]] and ttKeyboard{{Cite web|url=https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.myopenware.ttkeyboard.latin&hl=en|title=TTKeyboard ‚Äì Myanmar Keyboard|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}} allow for more forgiving input sequences and Zawgyi keyboard layouts which produce Unicode-compliant text. A number of Unicode-compliant Burmese fonts exist. The national standard keyboard layout is known as the Myanmar3 layout, and it was published along with the Myanmar3 Unicode font. The layout, developed by the [[Myanmar Unicode and NLP Research Center]], has a smart input system to cover the complex structures of Burmese and related scripts. In addition to the development of computer fonts and standard keyboard layout, there is still a lot of scope of research for the Burmese language, specifically for Natural Language Processing (NLP) areas like WordNet, Search Engine, development of parallel corpus for Burmese language as well as development of a formally standardized and dense domain-specific corpus of Burmese language.{{sfn|Saini|2016|p=8}} == Notes == {{reflist|20em}} == References == {{refbegin|30em}} * {{cite book|ref=harv|title=The Unicode Standard Version 6.1 ‚Äì Core Specification|editor=Julie D. The ''[[High Times]]'' '''Cannabis Cup''' is the world‚Äôs foremost [[cannabis (drug)|cannabis]] festival. Founded in 1988 by [[Steven Hager]], the ''High Times'' Cannabis Cup is held each November in [[Amsterdam]]. The event allows judges from around the world to sample and vote for their favorite marijuana varieties. These judges-at-large decide the Cannabis Cup (overall winner in the cannabis variety competition), best new product, best booth, best glass, best [[hashish|hash]] and best Nederhash. A team of VIP judges decides which seed company has grown the best ''indica'', ''sativa'' and hybrid strain and which company has produced the best Neder hash (hashish that is produced only in the Netherlands) and best imported hash. The ''High Times'' Cannabis Cup also includes live music, educational seminars and an expo for marijuana-related products from cannabis-oriented businesses.
In 2010, ''High Times'' mounted its first Cannabis Cup in the United States. The magazine now holds Cannabis Cups in Northern and Southern California, Denver, Michigan, Seattle, with plans to hold a Cannabis Cup in Portland in 2015. The ''High Times'' Medical Cannabis Cup celebrates medical marijuana in states that have passed medical marijuana laws. The U.S. Cannabis Cup celebrates marijuana in states that have passed laws that legalize marijuana for adult, recreational use. Like the ''High Times'' Cannabis Cup in Amsterdam, marijuana strains are judged and Cups (trophies) are awarded in a number of categories. Teams of expert judges vote on best ''indica'', best ''sativa'', best hybrid, best concentrates, best edibles and highest level of CBD in cannabis products. Attendees vote for best booth, best products and best glass of each Cannabis Cup expo.
All cannabis products are additionally tested for THC content and CBD content by independent cannabis testing laboratories.
In 2014, Amsterdam saw its last and final ''High Times'' Cannabis Cup, after 27 years of the cup in Amsterdam. This was partly due to the growing uncertainty about Dutch cannabis laws, the now available warmer, legal cannabis locations in the United States and various other countries, and the ill-fated and first ever police raid on the 2010 Amsterdam Cannabis Cup location.
In 2017, the festival celebrated its 30th anniversary. The festival featured an award show hosted by Danny Danko.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://hightimes.com/news/winners-2017-amsterdam-cannabis-cup/|title=Winners Of The 2017 Amsterdam Cannabis Cup ¬∑ High Times|website=hightimes.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-01-30}}</ref>
==Counterculture Hall of Fame== {{Main article|Counterculture Hall of Fame}}
Created in 1997 to celebrate the history of the counterculture and the people who helped shape it, the [[Counterculture Hall of Fame]] holds its induction ceremony during the ''High Times'' Cannabis Cup each November. Previous inductees include [[Bob Marley]] (1997), [[Louis Armstrong]] (1998), [[William S. Burroughs]], [[Allen Ginsberg]], and [[Jack Kerouac]] (1999), [[Bob Dylan]] (2002), [[Jack Herer]] (2003), [[Tommy Chong]] and [[Cheech Marin]] (2007), [[Peter Tosh]] (2008) [[Tom Forcade]] (2009) and [[Coke La Rock]] (2010). John Griggs, BEL (2011), Steve Hager (2012), Ben Dronkers (2013), and [[Alexander Shulgin]] & [[Ann Shulgin]] (2014).
==Film== A DVD called ''High Times Presents: The Cannabis Cup'' was made after 2003's festival. A film of the 2007 ''High Times'' Cannabis Cup, which marked the event's 20th anniversary, was released in the summer of 2008. The 20th ''High Times'' Cannabis Cup featured hosts Tommy Chong and Redman.

{{more citations needed|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox prepared food | name = Cocido madrile√±o | image = CocidoMadrile√±o.jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = Part of a ''cocido'' serving, with [[chickpeas]], [[vegetables]] and [[meat]] | alternate_name = | country = [[Spain]] | region = [[Madrid]] | creator = | course = [[Appetiser]] or [[main course]] | served = Hot | main_ingredient = [[Chickpea]]s | variations = | calories = | other = }}
'''''Cocido madrile√±o''''' ("Madrilenian stew", {{IPA-es|koÀàŒ∏i√∞o ma√∞…æiÀàle…≤o}}) is a traditional [[chickpea]]-based [[stew]] from [[Madrid]], [[Spain]]. A substantial dish prepared with meat and vegetables, it is most popular during the winter but is served throughout the year in some restaurants.
==History== The origins of the dish are uncertain, but most sources agree that probably it was created during the [[Middle Ages]] as an evolution of the [[Sephardic]] dish [[adafina]]. Long-cooking dishes were indispensable for [[Spanish and Portuguese Jews|Jews]] as they allowed hearty meals during [[Shabbat]]. These first versions were [[kosher]], using [[Egg (food)|eggs]] and without [[pork]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Daft|first1=Rohan|title=Menu Del Dia: More Than 100 Classic, Authentic Recipes From Across Spain|date=2008|publisher=Simon and Schuster|isbn=9781416579618|page=74|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=ohvX5Wih5EwC&pg=PA74&dq=Cocido+madrile%C3%B1o+sephardic&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwician7yZbbAhXLbRQKHeR2AacQ6AEIKTAA#v=onepage&q=Cocido%20madrile%C3%B1o%20sephardic&f=false|accessdate=21 May 2018|language=en}}</ref> Within time, adafina was soon popular elsewhere{{Where?|date=May 2015}}.
The growth of [[anti-Semitism]] and the [[Inquisition]] during the 15th and 16th centuries modified the dish substantially, as the fear of being denounced as Jewish forced [[Christians]] and ''[[Marranos]]'' (converted Jews) alike to prove themselves as Christians by incorporating pork into their meals. Soon [[lard]], [[bacon]], ''[[chorizo]]'' (pork sausage) and ''[[morcilla]]'' (blood sausage) were added to the dish.<ref>http://www.spain-recipes.com/cocido-recipe.html</ref>
From these origins, the recipe allowed few modifications and was soon established as a staple of [[Madrid]] cuisine. During the growth of the city in the 19th and 20th centuries, its low cost and heartiness made it a popular order in small [[restaurants]] and the [[taverns]] catering to manual workers. After the [[Spanish Civil War|Civil War]], the austerity period, followed by the introduction of more convenient meals, reduced the public popularity of the dish.
==Ingredients== [[File:Cozido madrileno.jpg|thumb|Cocido madrile√±o]] The main ingredient of ''cocido'' is the [[chickpea]] or ''garbanzo''. Vegetables are added: [[potatoes]] mainly, but also [[cabbage]], [[carrots]], and [[turnips]]. In some cases, [[green bean]], [[Chard|mangold]] and [[cardoon]] are also added.
The meat used is fundamentally [[pork]]: [[pork belly]], usually fresh, but sometimes [[Curing (food preservation)|cured]] (some purists even insist to a point of [[Rancidification|rancidity]]); fresh (unsmoked) ''[[chorizo]]''; [[onion]] ''[[morcilla]]'', and dried and cured [[jam√≥n serrano]]. [[Beef shank]] is also added; the [[fat]] content (''flor'') of the piece is highly prized. [[Chicken]] (especially old [[wikt:hen|hens]]) is also part of the ''cocido''.
Two [[bone]] pieces ([[ham]] bone and [[beef]] [[Vertebral column|spine]] bone) are added to enrich the [[stock (food)|stock]].
For some recipes, the final touch is the ''bola'', a [[meatball]]-like mix of [[ground beef]], [[bread crumbs]], [[parsley]] and other [[spices]], which, it is said,{{citation needed|date=May 2015}} was created as a substitute of the eggs used in the ''adafaina''.
==On the table== Tradition rules that the ingredients of ''cocido'' must be served separately. Each serving is known as a ''vuelco'' (tipping or emptying out), as at each time the [[Cooking pot|pot]] must be emptied out to separate the ingredients.
The first ''vuelco'' is to separate the [[stock (food)|stock]] of the ''cocido'' and serve it with [[noodles]] added. The second ''vuelco'' consists of the chickpeas and the vegetables. The third ''vuelco'' is the meat dish.
==Leftovers== Traditionally, dishes made with the leftovers of the ''cocido'' include Spanish ''croquetas'' ([[croquettes]]), ''[[ropa vieja]]'' and ''[[pring√°]]''.
==See also== * ''[[Cocido lebaniego]]'' * ''[[Cocido monta√±√©s]]'' * ''[[Cozido √† portuguesa]]'' * ''[[Fabada|Fabada asturiana]]'' * [[List of stews]] * [[Spanish cuisine]]

Culture of the Republic of the Congo is rich, diverse and made up of a mix of about 4.5 million people in 2015 and just as many languages and customs.
Half of [[republic of the Congo|Congolese]] people follow traditional beliefs, and there are 15 principle [[Bantu peoples|Bantu]] groups and more than 70 subgroups. The other half are 35% [[Roman Catholic]], 15% other Christian and 2% [[Muslim]]. The region was dominated by Bantu-speaking tribes, who built trade links leading into the Congo River basin. Congo-Brazzaville was formerly part of the French colony of Equatorial Africa.
==Language and writings==
The official language of the Republic of Congo is French. French is spoken by 56% of the Congolese population (78% of the population over 10 years), the second highest percentage of Africa in 2010, behind that of Gabon2. About 88% of Brazzavillans over 15 years of age say they have an easy expression in French. The Republic of Congo has a number of well-known writers in Africa and the French-speaking world: [[Alain Mabanckou]], [[Jean-Baptiste Tati Loutard]], [[Jeannette Balou Tchichelle]], [[Henri Lopes]], [[Lassy Mbouity]] and [[Tchicaya U Tam'si]].
Several artistic genres such as Congolese cinema struggle to make their breakthrough. After a promising start in the 1970s, the turbulent political environment and the closing of cinemas made production difficult. The country produces no feature films a year and filmmakers broadcast their production directly in video. In the end, in Congo-Brazzaville, culture remained until then the poor relation of the investments of successive governments.

{{Distinguish|Disability rights}} {{more citations needed|date=October 2012}} {{Disability}} '''Disability studies''' is an academic discipline that examines the meaning, nature, and consequences of [[disability]]. Initially the field focused on the division between "impairment" and "disability", where impairment was an impairment of an individual's mind or body, while disability was considered a [[social constructionism|social construct]].{{cite web|title=Session Details: Avenues of Access: The State of Disability Studies|url=http://www.mla.org/conv_listings_detail?prog_id=570&year=2013|website=Modern Language Association|publisher=Modern Language Association|accessdate=26 March 2015}} This premise gave rise to two distinct models of disability: the [[Social model of disability|social]] and [[medical model of disability|medical]] models of disability. In 1999 the social model was universally accepted as the model preferred by the field.{{cite journal|last1=Bickenbacha|first1=Jerome E|last2=Chatterji|first2=Somnath|last3=Badley|first3=E.M.|last4=√úst√ºn|first4=T.B.|title=Models of disablement, universalism and the international classification of impairments, disabilities and handicaps|journal=Social Science & Medicine|date=1999|volume=48|issue=9|pages=1173‚Äì1187|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0277953698004419%20/%20bbib10|accessdate=26 March 2015|doi=10.1016/s0277-9536(98)00441-9}} However, in recent years, the division between the social and medical models has been challenged.{{cite journal|last1=Dewsbury|first1=Guy|last2=Karen|first2=Clarke|last3=Randallb|first3=Dave|last4=Rouncefield|first4=Mark|last5=Sommerville|first5=Ian|title=The anti‚Äêsocial model of disability|journal=Disability & Society|date=Oct 2010|volume=19|issue=2|pages=145‚Äì158|doi=10.1080/0968759042000181776|citeseerx=10.1.1.140.9006}} Additionally there has been an increased focus on interdisciplinary research.{{cite web|title=what is disability studies?|url=https://www.disstudies.org/about/what_is_ds|website=Society for Disability Studies|accessdate=26 March 2015}} For example, recent investigations suggest using "cross-sectional markers of stratification"{{cite journal | last1 = Siordia | first1 = C | year = 2014 | title = Disability Prevalence According to a Class, Race, and Sex (CRS) Hypothesis | url = | journal = Journal of Racial & Ethnic Health Disparities | volume = 2| issue = 3| pages = 303‚Äì310| doi = 10.1007/s40615-014-0073-8 | pmid = 26539340 | pmc = 4628829}} may help provide new insights on the non-random distribution of risk factors capable of acerbating disablement processes. Disability studies courses include work in disability history, theory, legislation, policy, ethics, and the arts. However, students are taught to focus on the lived experiences of individuals with disabilities in practical terms. The field is focused on increasing individuals with disabilities access to [[civil rights]] and improving their [[quality of life]].{{cite news|last1=CAPUZZI SIMON|first1=CECILIA|title=Disability Studies: A New Normal|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/03/education/edlife/disability-studies-a-new-normal.html?_r=0|accessdate=26 March 2015|publisher=The New York Times|date=1 November 2013}} Disability studies emerged in the 1980s primarily in the US, the UK, and Canada. In 1986, the Section for the Study of Chronic Illness, Impairment, and Disability of the Social Science Association (United States) was renamed the [[Society for Disability Studies]].{{cite web|title=Mission and History|url=https://www.disstudies.org/about/mission-and-history|website=Society for Disability Studies|accessdate=26 March 2015}} The first US disabilities studies program emerged in 1994, at [[Syracuse University]]. The first edition of the Disabilities Studies Reader (one of the first collections of academic papers related to disability studies) was published in 1997.{{cite book|editor-last=Davis|editor-first=Lennard J.|title=The disability studies reader|date=1997|publisher=Routledge|location=New York|isbn=9780415914703}} The field grew rapidly over the next ten years. In 2005, the [[Modern Language Association]] established disability studies as a ‚Äúdivision of study.‚Äù ==History== Universities have long studied disabilities from a clinical perspective. In 1986 the Section for the Study of Chronic Illness, Impairment, and Disability of Social Science Association was renamed the [[Society for Disability Studies]] and its journal "[[Disability Studies Quarterly]]" was the first journal in disability studies. The first US disabilities studies program emerged in 1994, at [[Syracuse University]]. However, courses and programs were very few. In the 1997 first edition of the "Disability Studies Reader" Lennard J. Davis wrote that "it had been virtually impossible to have someone teaching about disability within the humanities". In the second edition, written ten years later, he writes that "all that has changed", but "just because disability studies is on the map, does not mean that is easy to find".{{cite book|editor1-last=Davis|editor1-first=Lennard J.|title=The disability studies reader|date=2006|publisher=Routledge|location=New York|isbn=9780415953337|edition=2nd}} Still the field continued to grow throughout the 2000s. In 2009 Disability Studies Quarterly published a A Multinational Review of English-language Disability Studies Degrees and Courses. They found that from 2003 to 2008 the number of disability studies stand alone studies courses in the US, UK, Australia, New Zealand and Canada grew from 56 to 108 and the number of degree granting courses grew from 212 to 420. A total of 17 degrees in disability studies were offered, with 11 programs in the US, 2 in the UK, 3 in Canada, and one in Australia.{{cite journal|title=A Multinational Review Of English-Language Disability Studies Degrees And Courses|journal=Disability Studies Quarterly|date=2009|volume=29|issue=3|url=http://dsq-sds.org/issue/view/41|accessdate=26 March 2015|doi=10.18061/dsq.v29i3.940 | last1 = Cushing | first1 = Pamela | last2 = Smith | first2 = Tyler}} A 2014 [[New York Times]] article "Disability Studies: A New Normal" suggests that the expansion in disability studies programs is related to the 1990 passage of the [[Americans with Disabilities Act]] (ADA). Those raised after the passage of the ADA have entered colleges and the workforce, as Disability Studies has grown. In a 2014 article, Disability Studies Quarterly published an analysis on the relationships between student run groups and disability studies, from 2008 to 2012. Their article analyzes groups at four different universities and describes how professors have incorporated student activism into their curriculum and research.{{cite journal|last1=Stout|first1=Allegra|last2=Schwartz|first2=Ariel|title="It'll Grow Organically and Naturally": The Reciprocal Relationship between Student Groups and Disability Studies on College Campuses|journal=Disability Studies Quarterly|date=2014|volume=34|issue=2|url=http://dsq-sds.org/article/view/4253/3593|accessdate=26 March 2015|doi=10.18061/dsq.v34i2.4253}} ==Definitions== According to the transnational{{cite web|title=About|url=http://disstudies.org/about|website=Society for Disability Studies|accessdate=26 March 2015}} [[Society for Disability Studies]]:
"Using an interdisciplinary, multidisciplinary approach. Disability sits at the intersection of many overlapping disciplines in the humanities, sciences, and social sciences. Programs in Disability Studies should encourage a curriculum that allows students, activists, teachers, artists, practitioners, and researchers to engage the subject matter from various disciplinary perspectives. *Challenging the view of disability as an individual deficit or defect that can be remedied solely through medical intervention or rehabilitation by "experts" and other service providers. Rather, a program in Disability Studies should explore models and theories that examine social, political, cultural, and economic factors that define disability and help determine personal and collective responses to difference. At the same time, Disability Studies should work to de-stigmatize disease, illness, and impairment, including those that cannot be measured or explained by biological science. Finally, while acknowledging that medical research and intervention can be useful, Disability Studies should interrogate the connections between medical practice and stigmatizing disability. *Studying national and international perspectives, policies, literature, culture, and history with an aim of placing current ideas of disability within their broadest possible context. Since attitudes toward disability have not been the same across times and places, much can be gained by learning from these other experiences. *Encouraging participation by disabled students and faculty, and ensuring physical and intellectual access. Prioritizing leadership positions held by disabled people; at the same time, it is important to create an environment where contributions from anyone who shares the above goals are welcome."
==Disability studies and medical humanities== The [[social model of disability]] is expanded to chronic illness and to the broader work of the [[medical humanities]].{{cite journal|last=Garden|first=R|title=Disability and narrative: new directions for medicine and the medical humanities|journal=Medical Humanities|date=December 2010|volume=36|issue=2|pages=70‚Äì4|pmid=21393285|doi=10.1136/jmh.2010.004143}} Practitioners are working towards improving the healthcare for disabled people through disability studies. This multi-disciplinary field of inquiry draws on the experiences and perspectives of people with disabilities to address discrimination. [[Infinite Ability]] has done some preliminary work in [[India]] to introduce disability studies to medical students.{{cite journal|last=Singh|first=S|author2=Khosla, J |author3=Sridhar, S |title=Exploring medical humanities through theatre of the oppressed|journal=Indian Journal of Psychiatry|date=July 2012|volume=54|issue=3|pages=296‚Äì7|pmid=23226869|doi=10.4103/0019-5545.102461|pmc=3512382}}{{cite journal|last=Khetarpal|first=A|author2=Singh, S|title=Infertility: Why can't we classify this inability as disability?|journal=The Australasian Medical Journal|year=2012|volume=5|issue=6|pages=334‚Äì9|pmid=22848333|doi=10.4066/AMJ.2012.1290|pmc=3395292}}{{cite journal|last=Singh|first=S|title=Broadening horizons: looking beyond disability|journal=Medical Education|date=May 2012|volume=46|issue=5|page=522|pmid=22515781|doi=10.1111/j.1365-2923.2012.04246.x}} ==Intersectionality== [[Feminism]] introduces the inclusion of [[intersectionality]] in disability studies. It focuses on [[race (human categorization)|race]], [[gender]], [[Human sexuality|sexuality]], [[Class (social)|class]] and other related systems of [[oppression]] that can also intersect with having a disability.{{Cite journal|last=Gillborn|first=David|date=2015|title=Intersectionality, Critical Race Theory, and the Primacy of Racism: Race, Class, Gender, and Disability in Education.|journal=Qualitative Inquiry|language=en|volume=3|issue=3|pages=277‚Äì287|doi=10.1177/1077800414557827}} From a feminism standpoint, there is a large concern for grasping multiple positions and differences among social groups.{{Cite journal|last1=Tina Goethals|first=|last2=Elisabeth De Schauwer|last3=Geert Van Hove|date=|year=2015|title=Weaving Intersectionality into Disability Studies Research: Inclusion, Reflexivity and Anti-Essentialism|url=https://www.jstor.org/stable/pdf/10.11116/jdivegendstud.2.1-2.0075.pdf?refreqid=excelsior:000f48af9d031f8db8036895074aa270|journal=Digest. Journal of Diversity and Gender Studies|language=en|volume=2|pages=75|doi=10.11116/jdivegendstud.2.1-2.0075|via=}} Some research on intersectionality and disability has focused on the aspect of being part of two or more stigmatized groups and how these are contributing factors to multiple forms of harassment, the paradox known as "Double Jeopardy".{{Cite journal|last=Shaw|first=Linda R.|last2=Chan|first2=Fong|last3=McMahon|first3=Brian T.|date=2011-12-29|title=Intersectionality and Disability Harassment|journal=Rehabilitation Counseling Bulletin|language=en|volume=55|issue=2|pages=82‚Äì91|doi=10.1177/0034355211431167|issn=0034-3552}} ===Race=== Recent scholarship has included studies that explore the intersection between disability and race. Ellen Samuels explores [[Gender studies|gender]], queer sexualities, and disability.{{cite web|url=http://www.womenstudies.wisc.edu/professional-pages/samuels.htm|title=Department of Gender and Women's Studies|date=2013-02-27|publisher=Womenstudies.wisc.edu|accessdate=2013-05-07}}{{cite web|url=http://disabilitystudies.syr.edu/resources/feministdisabilitystudies.aspx|title=Women and Disability: Feminist Disability Studies [Disability Studies]|publisher=Disabilitystudies.syr.edu|accessdate=2013-05-07}} [[Christopher Bell (scholar)|Christopher Bell]]‚Äôs posthumous{{cite web|url=http://media-dis-n-dat.blogspot.ca/2009/12/obituary-chris-bell-disability-studies.html|title=Media dis&dat: Obituary: Chris Bell, disability studies scholar on race, HIV/AIDS, dies|author=BA Haller|date=2009-12-26|publisher=Media-dis-n-dat.blogspot.ca|accessdate=2013-05-07}} volume on ''Blackness and Disability'';{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2N8uMz6g02gC|title=Blackness and Disability: Critical Examinations and Cultural Interventions - Google Boeken|year=2011|isbn=9783643101266|accessdate=2013-05-07|last1=Bell|first1=Christopher M.}} and the work of [[Robert McRuer]] both explore [[Queer theory|queerness]] and disability. These works engage with issues of [[Neoliberalism|neoliberal]] economic oppression. Scholars of Feminist Disability Studies include [[Rosemarie Garland-Thomson]] and Alison Kafer. {{Citation needed|date=March 2014}} The 2009 publication of Fiona Kumari Campbell‚Äôs "Contours of Ableism: The Production of Disability and Abledness" signalled a new direction of research ‚Äî studies in ableism, moving beyond preoccupations with disability to explore the maintenance of abledness in sexed, raced and modified bodies.{{Citation needed|date=March 2014}} Similarly, recent work has focused on the intersections of race and ethnicity with disability in the field of education studies and attempted to bridge Critical Race Studies with Dis/ability studies.{{Cite journal|last=Annamma|first=Subini Ancy|date=18 November 2015|title=Dis/ability critical race studies (DisCrit): theorizing at theintersections of race and dis/ability|url=https://www.academia.edu/2258717|journal=Race Ethnicity and Education|volume=16|issue=1|pages=1‚Äì31|doi=|pmid=|access-date=}} This work reflects an effort to deal with complex histories of marking racially "othered" bodies as physically, psychologically, or morally deficient, and traces this history of scientific racism to contemporary dynamics. Empirical studies show that minority students are disproportionately more likely to be removed from class or school for "behavioral" or academic reasons, and far more likely to be labeled with intellectual or learning disabilities.{{Cite journal|last=Annamma|first=Subini Ancy|date=18 November 2015|title=Dis/ability critical race studies(DisCrit): theorizing at theintersections of race and dis/ability|url=https://www.academia.edu/2258717|journal=Race Ethnicity and Education|volume=16|issue=1|pages=1‚Äì31|doi=|pmid=|access-date=}} The authors propose a union of critical race and disability studies, DisCrit, as an intersectional approach designed to analyzing the interaction between ableism, sexism, and racism. In addition to work by individual scholars, disability studies organizations have also begun to focus on disability and race and gender. The Society for Disability Studies created the Chris Bell Memorial Scholarship to honor Bell's commitment to diversity in disability studies.{{cite web|url=https://www.disstudies.org/awards/chris-bell|title=chris bell memorial scholarship|website=Society for Disability Studies|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402160435/https://www.disstudies.org/awards/chris-bell|archivedate=2 April 2015|deadurl=yes|accessdate=26 March 2015|df=}} Postsecondary disability studies programs increasingly engage with the [[intersectionality]] of oppression. The [[University of Manitoba]] offers a course in on "Women with disabilities".{{cite web|url=http://umanitoba.ca/disability_studies/contents/courses.html|title=Disability Studies Courses|website=University of Manitoba|accessdate=26 March 2015}} Several recent masters' student research papers at [[York University]] focus on issues related to women with disabilities and people of African descent with disabilities.{{cite web|url=http://cdis.gradstudies.yorku.ca/ma/mrp/|title=COMPLETED MA PROJECT RESEARCH PAPERS|website=York University|accessdate=26 March 2015}} ===Feminism=== Feminism integrates the social and political aspects that makes a body oppressed while allowing empowerment to be present in acknowledging its culture. [[Rosemarie Garland-Thomson]] explains that these related systems of oppression pervades all aspects of culture by "its structuring institutions, social identities, cultural practices, political positions, historical communities, and the shared human experience of embodiment". Garland-Thomson further describes that "identity based critical enterprises have enriched and complicated our understandings of social justice, subject formation, subjugated knowledges and collective action".{{Cite journal|title=Garland-Thomson, Rosemarie. "Integrating disability, transforming feminist theory." NWSA journal 14.3 (2002): 1-32|journal=|volume=}} Feminism works towards [[accessibility]] for everyone regardless of which societal oppressive behavior makes them a [[minority group|minority]]. Although physical adjustments are most commonly fought for in disability awareness, psychological exclusion also plays a major role oppressing people with disabilities. [[Sara Ahmed]] elaborates the mental exclusiveness of privilege in "Atmospheric Walls", that there is an atmosphere that surrounds minority bodies which explains why an intersectionally privileged person could be made uncomfortable simply by being in the same room as a person of color, or in this case someone with a disability.{{Cite journal|title=Ahmed, Sara N. "Atmospheric Walls." Feministkilljoys. N.p., 2014. Web. 10 Oct. 2016|journal=|volume=}} Feminists and scholars also developed theories that put attention on the connection of gender and disability. Scholars like Thomas J. Gerschick argued that disability plays a big role on processing and experiencing gender, and people with disabilities often suffer stigmatization towards their gender, since their disabilities may make their body representation excluded by normative binary gender representation.{{Cite journal|last=Gerschick|first=Thomas J.|date=2000-07-01|title=Toward a Theory of Disability and Gender|journal=Signs: Journal of Women in Culture and Society|volume=25|issue=4|pages=1263‚Äì1268|doi=10.1086/495558|issn=0097-9740}} Gerschick also argues that this stigmatization can affect the gendering process and self-representation of people with disabilities. Feminists also look into how people with disabilities are politically oppressed and powerless. Abby L. Wilkerson argues that people with disabilities are politically powerless because they are often desexualized, and the lack of sexual agency leads to the lack of political agency. Wilkerson also indicates that the erotophobia towards minority groups like people with disabilities further oppresses them, since it prevents these groups from gaining political power through sexual agency and power.{{Cite journal|last=Wilkerson|first=Abby|date=2002|title=Disability, Sex Radicalism, and Political Agency|jstor=4316923|journal=NWSA Journal|volume=14|issue=3|pages=33‚Äì57}} ===Gender and sexuality=== The intersectionality of disability and LGBTQ communities is a more modern subject of study in which the relevance, historically, came about mostly in the 1960s and the 1970s with the surge of advocates in the midst of the vocal liberation and civil rights movements.{{citation needed|date=May 2017}} These communities on their own are topics of numerous deliberations, however they also often link in significance in many ways. The significance of the movements however, began to build momentum and most legal recognition in the 1980s. It was from this age of advocacy that the intersectionality of these two minority groups came into a more clear focus, though it is one continuously growing subject of discussion.{{citation needed|date=May 2017}} It was only in 1973 that the [[American Psychiatric Association]] removed homosexuality from their list of mental disorders.{{Cite journal|last=Drescher|first=Jack|date=2015|title=Out of DSM: Depathologizing Homosexuality|journal=Behavioral Sciences|volume=5|issue=4|pages=565‚Äì575|pmc=4695779|pmid=26690228|doi=10.3390/bs5040565}} In addition to this, it was about forty years later in 2013 that the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition ([[DSM-5]]) changed the listing of transgender to ‚Äúgender dysphoria‚Äù.{{Cite book|title=Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders|last=American Psychiatric Association|date=2013-05-22|publisher=American Psychiatric Association|isbn=978-0890425558|language=en|doi=10.1176/appi.books.9780890425596}} One of the most notable circumstances where the case of these two minority rights come together was the court case ''[[In re Guardianship of Kowalski]]'', in which an accident that occurred in 1983 left a thirty-six year old Sharon Kowalski physically disabled with severe brain injuries.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/08/07/us/gay-groups-are-rallied-to-aid-2-women-s-fight.html|title=Gay Groups Are Rallied To Aid 2 Women's Fight|last=Brozan|first=Nadine|access-date=2018-10-18|language=en}} The court granted guardianship of her to her homophobic parents who refused visitation rights to her long time partner, Karen Thompson. The court case lasted nearly ten years and was resolved by granting Thompson custody in 1991.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/18/us/disabled-woman-s-care-given-to-lesbian-partner.html|title=Disabled Woman's Care Given to Lesbian Partner|last=Lewin|first=Tamar|access-date=2018-10-07|language=en}} This was a major victory in the realm of gay rights but also called to attention the validity of rights for those who identified under the queer and disabled spectrum. Numerous support groups emerged from necessity to create safe spaces for those identifying in these specific minority groups such as the founding of the Rainbow Alliance of the Deaf in 1977,{{citation needed|date=May 2017}} the Lesbian Disabled Veterans of America group in 1996{{citation needed|date=May 2017}} which then became the Gay, Lesbian, Bisexual and Transgender Disabled Veterans of America, and the San Francisco Gay Amputees group in 2006. A 2012 study showed that disability was more common in gay, lesbian, and bisexual individuals when compared to heterosexual peers.{{Cite journal|last=Fredriksen-Goldsen|first=Karen I.|last2=Kim|first2=Hyun-Jun|last3=Barkan|first3=Susan E.|date=2012|title=Disability Among Lesbian, Gay, and Bisexual Adults: Disparities in Prevalence and Risk|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3490559/|journal=American Journal of Public Health|volume=102|issue=1|pages=e16‚Äìe21|doi=10.2105/AJPH.2011.300379|issn=0090-0036|pmc=3490559|pmid=22095356|via=}} It was also shown that the gay, lesbian, and bisexual group with disabilities were noticeably younger in age than the heterosexual group. There was a significant difference in the prevalence of mental and physical health between the study groups, a higher statistic of those with queer identities having issues health wise than those straight identifying, reportedly due to the weight of social pressure and discrimination of minority sexual identities.{{citation needed|date=May 2017}} Though these minority groups do not always intersect, the way they handle their own discrimination, can be compared in similar ways.{{citation needed|date=May 2017}} Being that both the LGBTQ rights movement and the disability rights movements have been defined as minority discrimination movements, it has been said{{by whom|date=May 2017}} that they are a direct contrast to society normalizing the dominance of heterosexuality and able-bodiedness in its majority population. It is also a large topic of discussion to say that both groups have to undergo the same kind of "coming out" process in terms of their sexual identity, gender identity, and disability identity because of the lasting social stigma.{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=2015|title=Addressing Disability Stigma within the Lesbian Community|url=https://s3.amazonaws.com/academia.edu.documents/43888838/Lesbian___Disability.pdf?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAIWOWYYGZ2Y53UL3A&Expires=1539886805&Signature=JzL0VYPNkGAJAKigLgay9NP0i%2F0%3D&response-content-disposition=inline%3B%20filename%3DAddressing_Disability_Stigma_within_the.pdf|journal=Journal of Rehabilitation|volume=81|pages=49‚Äì56|via=}} "Coming out" through sexual identity, gender identity, and disability identity is one example of "Double Jeopardy", as they are part of more than one stigmatized group. [[Queer studies]] which emerged from [[women's studies]], brings light towards the different kind of oppression [[queer]] and [[transgender]] people with disabilities have. For example, the [[Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990|Americans with Disabilities Act]] dismisses [[gender disphoria]] because of its moral case against transgender people.{{Cite journal|last=Barry |first=Kevin M. |title=Disabilityqueer: Federal Disability Rights Protection for Transgender People |date=February 18, 2014 |journal=Yale Human Rights and Development Law Journal |volume=16 |issue=1 |page=1 |url=https://digitalcommons.law.yale.edu/yhrdlj/vol16/iss1/1/ }} Queer studies are commonly associated with people with disabilities who identify as ‚ÄúCrip‚Äù and is commonly believed that queer politics must incorporate crip politics.{{Cite web|last=McRuer |first=Robert |title=Cripping Queer Politics, or the Dangers of Neoliberalism |website=S&F Online |url=http://sfonline.barnard.edu/a-new-queer-agenda/cripping-queer-politics-or-the-dangers-of-neoliberalism/ |issue=10.1‚Äì10.2 |date=Fall 2011 ‚Äì Spring 2012}} Alison Kafer describes a first person experience of identifying queer and crip both bold reappropriated terms in Kafer's novel, "Feminist Queer Crip". Kafer describes the politics of the crip future and "an insistence on thinking these imagined futures - and hence, these lived presents - differently".{{cite book|last1=Kafer|first1=Alison|title=Feminist, queer, crip|date=2013|publisher=Indiana University Press|location=Bloomington|isbn=9780253009227}} Although many activists with disabilities find empowerment in appropriating the term crip, not all people with disabilities feel comfortable using that identity.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=V3GPb2obU0gC&pg=PR5&dq=Crip+Theory:+Cultural+Signs+of+Queerness+and+Disability#v=onepage&q=Crip%20Theory:%20Cultural%20Signs%20of%20Queerness%20and%20Disability&f=false|title=Crip Theory: Cultural Signs of Queerness and Disability|last=McRuer|first=Robert|date=2006-06-01|publisher=NYU Press|isbn=9780814761090|language=en}} There are many different terms used as an alternative to disability, for example Melwood, a nonprofit who uses the term "differing abilities", describes the label disability as "a limitation in the ability to pursue an occupation because of a physical or mental impairment; a disqualification, restriction or disadvantage and a lack of legal qualification to do something, was an inadequate or limiting 'label' for a cross section of people".{{cite web|title="Disabilities" vs. "Differing Abilities" |url=https://www.melwood.org/disabilities-vs-differing-abilities|website=Melwood|accessdate=5 May 2017}} Because the term disability has a history of inferiority, it is believed by many that substituting the term will help eliminate the [[ableism]] that is embedded within it. Susan Wendell describes ableism in society "as a structure for people who have no weakness",{{cite journal|last=Wendell |first=Susan |title=Toward a Feminist Theory of Disability |journal=Hypatia |volume=4 |number=2 |year=1989 |pages=104‚Äì124 |jstor=3809809 |doi=10.1111/j.1527-2001.1989.tb00576.x}} this also applies to anyone who has any intersectional disadvantages. Feminism identifies these disadvantages and strategizes how to deconstruct the system that supports marginalizing specific groups of people. === Social class === Within class comes multiple avenues for intersectionality through disability. Disability looks different from a middle class, upper class, and lower class perspective, as well as through race, gender, and ethnicity. One's social class can contribute to when a person becomes disabled, rather it be sooner or later.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=F4X6yaiCNOcC&pg=PP2&dq=Feminist,+Queer,+Crip#v=onepage&q=Feminist,%20Queer,%20Crip&f=false|title=Feminist, Queer, Crip|last=Kafer|first=Alison|date=2013-05-16|publisher=Indiana University Press|isbn=978-0253009418|language=en}} For example, where there is poverty we will find disability.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=2zYEDQAAQBAJ&pg=PP1&dq=Disability+Studies:+An+Interdisciplinary+Introduction#v=onepage&q=Disability%20Studies:%20An%20Interdisciplinary%20Introduction&f=false|title=Disability Studies: An Interdisciplinary Introduction|last=Goodley|first=Dan|date=2016-11-03|publisher=SAGE|isbn=9781473986930|language=en}} This poverty can include social, economic, and cultural poverty. Having a disability can contribute to poverty just as poverty can contribute to having a disability.{{Cite book|title=Poverty and Disability: A Survey of the Literature|last=Elwan|first=Ann|publisher=|year=1999|isbn=|location=|pages=}} People with disabilities are more likely to live in poverty and be unemployed than those who do not, resulting in lower socioeconomic status.{{Cite web|url=https://www.apa.org/pi/ses/resources/publications/disability.aspx|title=Disability & Socioeconomic Status|last=|first=|date=|website=apa.org|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-07}} ==Criticism== ===Questioning the social model=== The International Association of Accessibility Professionals {{cite web|title=Certified Professional in Accessibility Core Competencies|url=http://www.accessibilityassociation.org/certificationprofoutline|website=International Association of Accessibility Professionals|accessdate=23 July 2016}} recognizes six different models for conceptualizing disability: social, medical, cultural affiliation, economic, charity, and functional solutions. Once universally accepted in the field, the '''social''' model of disability has recently{{When|date=January 2018}} been challenged. In a 2014 ''Disability Studies Quarterly'' article, students involved in campus disability groups note that they actively seek cures for their chronic illnesses and "question the rejection of the '''medical''' model" of disability. The '''cultural affiliation''' model accepts the person's disability completely and uses it a point of pride in being associated with other people in a similar condition.{{cite book|last1=Shapiro|first1=J|title=No Pity: People with Disabilities Forging a New Civil Rights Movement|date=1994|publisher=Broadway Books.}} The '''economic''' model recognizes the effect of bodily limitations on a person's ability to work, and there may be a need for economic support or accommodations for the person's disability {{cite book|last1=Strnadov√°|first1=I|last2=Cumming,|first2=Therese|title=Lifespan transitions and disability : A holistic perspective|date=2015|publisher=Routledge}} while the '''charity''' model regards people with disabilities as unfortunate and in need of assistance from the outside, with those providing charity viewed as benevolent contributors to a needy population. The '''functional solutions''' model of disability is a practical perspective that identifies the limitations (or "functional impairments") due to disability, with the intent to create and promote solutions to overcome those limitations. The primary task is to eliminate, or at least reduce, the impact of the functional limitations of the body through technological or methodological innovation. The pragmatism of the functional solution model deemphasizes the sociopolitical aspects of disability, and instead prioritizes inventiveness and entrepreneurship. This is the prevailing opinion behind compliance literature that promotes self-efficacy and self-advocacy skills for people with disabilities preparing for transition to independent living.{{cite web|url=http://www2.ed.gov/about/offices/list/ocr/transitionguide.html |title=Transition of Students With Disabilities To Postsecondary Education: A Guide for High School Educators |publisher=.ed.gov |date= 2018-09-25|accessdate=2016-08-25}} ===Exclusion of cognitive and mental disabilities=== There is discourse within disability studies to analyze the construction of ''mental illness.'' However, few post-structuralist disability scholars have focused their attention to impairments of the mind.{{cite book|last1=Thomas|first1=Carol|title=Sociologies of disability and illness : contested ideas in disability studies and medical sociology|date=2007|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|location=New York|isbn=978-1403936363|page=131|edition=1. publ.}} According to Carol Thomas, the Reader in Sociology at the Institute for Health Research, [[Lancaster University]], this may be because disability scholars have in the past considered only the barriers confronted by people with physical disabilities. The experience of impairment, cognitive disability, and mental illness had been absent from the discussion. It is unclear exactly which perspective of disability scholarship ‚Äúpsychological impairment‚Äù can fall under, and this has led to a hesitation on the part of scholars. Scholars such as [[Peter Beresford]] (2002) suggest "the development of a 'social model of madness and distress'" which would consider impairments of the mind. A '''display question''' is a type of [[question]] where the questioner already knows the answer. Display questions are used in [[language education]] in order to elicit language practice. They are contrasted with [[referential question]]s, questions for which the answer is not yet known. The use of referential questions is generally preferred to the use of display questions in [[communicative language teaching]].<ref name="RichardsSchmidt2009">{{cite book | editor1-last = Richards | editor1-first = Jack C. | editor2-last = Schmidt | editor2-first = Richard | title = Longman Dictionary of Language Teaching and Applied Linguistics | publisher = Longman | location = New York | year = 2009 | isbn = 978-1-4082-0460-3 | page = 178 }}</ref>
== Example ==
Richards and Schmidt give the following example:
:Q: Is this a book? :A: Yes, it's a book.<ref name="RichardsSchmidt2009" />

{{unreferenced|date=April 2011}} [[Image:Skegness4web.jpg|thumb|British seaside donkeys in [[Skegness]], [[Lincolnshire]], used for donkey rides on the beach.]]
'''Donkey rides''' are a traditional feature of [[seaside resort]]s in the [[United Kingdom]]. Children are allowed to ride [[donkey]]s on a sandy [[beach]] for a fee in summer months while on holiday, normally led in groups at walking pace. Typically, the donkeys used to have their names on their [[safety harness|harnesses]] so they could be identified by children and parents alike.
Donkey rides have been available since 1886 in [[Weston Super Mare]] and since 1895 in [[Bridlington]].
The tradition started in [[Victorian era|Victorian]] times, but is now much less popular. It is probable that the donkeys offered to ride on were originally working draught animals in the cockle industries around the coast.
