{{Refimprove|date=September 2009}} {{Infobox anthem | title = Du gamla, du fria | english_title = Thou ancient, Thou free | image = | image_size = | caption = |alt_title = "S√•ng till Norden" |en_alt_title = "Song to the North" | prefix = National | country = {{SWE}} | composer = Old Swedish [[folk music]]<ref>{{cite web|author1=Eva Danielson|author2=M√§rta Ramsten|title=Du gamla, du friska ‚Äì fr√•n folkvisa till nationals√•ng|url=http://musikverket.se/svensktvisarkiv/artikel/du-gamla-du-friska/|website=musikverket.se|publisher=Svenskt visarkiv / Musikverket|accessdate=3 June 2017|language=Swedish}}</ref> (arranged for orchestra by [[Edvin Kallstenius]], 1933)<ref name="Holm">{{cite web|last1=Holm|first1=Anna Lena|title=Edvin Kallstenius|url=http://musikverket.se/musikochteaterbiblioteket/arkivregistret/edvin-kallstenius-1881-1967/|website=musikverket.se|publisher=Musik- och teaterbiblioteket / Musikverket|accessdate=3 June 2017|language=Swedish|date=August 1991}}</ref> | author = [[Richard Dybeck]] | lyrics_date = 1844 | until = | sound = United States Navy Band - Sweden.ogg | sound_title = "Du gamla, du fria" (instrumental) }} {{Music of Sweden}} "'''{{lang|sv|Du gamla, du fria}}'''" ({{IPA-sv|d âÀê ¬≤…°amÀêla d âÀê ¬≤friÀê.a|-|}}, {{Lang-en|"Thou ancient, Thou free"}}) is the ''de facto'' [[national anthem]] of [[Sweden]]. It was originally named "'''{{lang|sv|S√•ng till Norden}}'''" ({{IPA-sv|Ààs…î≈ãÀê t…™l ÀànuÀê…ñ…õn|pron|}}, "Song to the [[Nordic countries|North]]"), but the [[incipit]] has since been adopted as the title.
==History== [[File:Du gamla, du fria.ogg|thumb|"Du gamla, du fria" (complete choir version).]] [[File:Satellite image of Sweden in March 2002.jpg|thumb|upright|The scenery that inspired the lyrics]] Although the [[Swedish constitution]] makes no mention of a national anthem, "Du gamla, du fria" enjoys universal recognition and is used, for example, at government ceremonies as well as sporting events. It first began to win recognition as a patriotic song in the 1890s, and the issue of its status was debated back and forth up until the 1930s. In 1938, the Swedish public service radio company [[Sveriges Radio]] started playing it at the end of transmitting in the evenings, which marked the beginning of the de facto status as national anthem the song has had since.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://nationalanthems.me/sweden-du-gamla-du-fria | title=Sweden: Du gamla, Du fria | publisher=NationalAnthems.me | accessdate=2011-08-08 }}</ref>
Despite the belief that it was adopted as the national anthem in 1866, no such recognition has ever been officially accorded. A kind of official recognition was when the King [[Oscar II]] rose in honour when the song was played, the first time in 1893. In 2000 the [[Riksdag]] committee rejected, as "unnecessary", a proposal to give the song legally official status, repeated later. The committee concluded that the song has been established as anthem by the people, not by the political system, and that it is good to keep it that way.
[[File:Richard Dybeck.jpg|thumb|300px|right|Richard Dybeck wrote the original lyrics in 1844.]] The original lyrics were written by [[Richard Dybeck]] in 1844, to the melody of a variant of the ballad ''K√§restans d√∂d''. The ballad type is classified as D 280 in [[The Types of the Scandinavian Medieval Ballad]]; the variant from [[V√§stmanland]] that Dybeck reproduced is classified as [[Sveriges Medeltida Ballader|SMB]] 133 G.<ref>[[Sveriges Medeltida Ballader]], Vol. 4:1, pp. 16-17</ref> It was recorded by Rosa Wretman in the beginning of the 1840s. Dybeck published the traditional text in ''Folk-lore I'', and the melody in 1845 in his ''Runa'', where he also published his new text "S√•ng till Norden" ["Song to/of the North"].
Dybeck himself originally wrote the beginning as "Du gamla, du friska" ({{Lang-en|"Thou ancient, Thou hale"}}), but in the late 1850s personally changed the lyrics to "Du gamla, du fria" (Thou ancient, Thou free). The song was already published in several song books and sung with "Du gamla, du friska", but a priest who had known Dybeck got the opportunity to tell the singer most associated with the song, opera singer [[Carl Fredrik Lundqvist]], about the change in the year 1900. From that point on, printings of the "friska" version ceased to be seen in song books, but a recording from 1905 where it is sung with "friska" still exists.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://cylinders.library.ucsb.edu/search.php?queryType=@attr%201=1016&query=Arvid+Asplund&num=1&start=2&sortBy=&sortOrder=ia|title=Cylinder Preservation and Digitization Project|last=Collections.|first=University of California, Santa Barbara. Library. Department of Special|date=2005-11-16|website=cylinders.library.ucsb.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-06-03}}</ref> The Swedish composer [[Edvin Kallstenius]] made an orchestral arrangement of the national anthem in 1933.<ref name="Holm" />
By the early 20th century, many regarded the song unsuitable as a national anthem. In the 1890s it started getting printed in song books in the section for patriotic songs, but as late as in the 1920s it was occasionally published just as "folk music". In 1899 a contest was held for writing a national anthem. It led to [[Verner von Heidenstam]] writing his "Sverige", but did not lead to any new national anthem.
[[Patriotism|Patriotic]] sentiment is notably absent from the text of the original two verses,{{Dubious|date=February 2011}} due to them being written in the spirit of [[Scandinavism]] popular at the time (''Norden'' in general refers to the [[Nordic countries]] in Swedish, Norwegian and Danish). After the song started to acquire its informal status as the national anthem, various people wrote additional verses to increase the "Swedishness" of the song. The aforementioned Lundqvist wrote his own third verse beginning with "Jag √§lskar dig Sverige" (I love thee, Sweden), [[Frans √ñsterblom]] wrote four verses beginning with "Jag √§lskar min hembygd" ("I love my native area") and [[Louise Ahl√©n]] in 1910 wrote two verses.{{cn|date=February 2013}}

{{more footnotes|date=January 2014}} '''Ethnoecology''' is the [[scientific method|scientific]] study of how different groups of people living in different locations understand the [[ecosystem]]s around them, and their relationships with surrounding environments.
It seeks valid, reliable understanding of how we as humans have interacted with the environment and how these intricate relationships have been sustained over time.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=mHj3RfaLCFYC&oi=fnd&pg=PR7&dq=ethnoecology&ots=xsl7-Ob-kj&sig=gkKc38x93_fuB0S3Bo9IDTKwRvw#v=onepage&q=ethnoecology&f=false|title=Ethnoecology: Situated Knowledge/located Lives|last=Nazarea|first=Virginia D.|date=1999-01-01|publisher=University of Arizona Press|isbn=9780816523641|language=en}}</ref>
The "ethno" (see [[ethnology]]) prefix in ethnoecology indicates a localized study of a people, and in conjunction with [[ecology]], signifies people's understanding and experience of environments around them. Ecology is the study of the interactions between living organisms and their environment; enthnoecology applies a human focused approach to this subject.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IryOAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA200&lpg=PA200&dq=latin+morpeme+ethno&source=bl&ots=7nRnF23dRA&sig=LqE5uvdEmUIlTDLCpYAogk8yOo0&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwjRxMjZk7TeAhWaHzQIHawABSMQ6AEwDnoECAIQAQ#v=onepage&q=latin%20morpeme%20ethno&f=false|title=General Linguistics|last=Robins|first=R. H.|date=2014-05-12|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781317887638|language=en}}</ref> The development of the field lies in applying indigenous knowledge of [[botany]] and placing it in a global context.
== History == Ethnoecology began with some of the early works of Dr. [[Hugh Popenoe]], an agronomist and tropical soil scientist who has worked with the University of Florida, the National Science Foundation, and the National Research Council. Popenoe has also worked with Dr [[Harold Conklin]], a cognitive anthropologist who did extensive linguistic and ethnoecological research in Southeast Asia. <sup>[<nowiki/>[[Wikipedia:Citation needed|''citation needed'']]]</sup>
In his 1954 dissertation "The Relation of the Hanunoo Culture to the Plant World", Harold Conklin coined the term ethnoecology when he described his approach as "ethnoecological". After earning his PhD, he began teaching at Columbia University while continuing his research among the Hanunoo.
In 1955, Conklin published one of his first ethnoecological studies. His "Hanunoo Color Categories" study helped scholars understand the relationship between classification systems and conceptualization of the world within cultures. In this experiment, Conklin discovered that people in various cultures recognize colors differently due to their unique classification system. Within his results he found that the Hanunoo uses two levels of colors. The first level consists of four basic terms of colors:; darkness, lightness, redness, and greenness. While, the second level was more abstract and consisted of hundreds of color classifications such as: texture, shininess, and moisture of objects also were used to classify objects.
Other anthropologists had a hard time understanding this color classification system because they often applied their own idea of color criteria to those of the Hanunoo. Conklin's studies were not only the breakthrough of ethnoecology, but they also helped develop the idea that other cultures conceptualize the world in their own terms, which helped to reduce ethnocentric views of those in western cultures. Other scholars such as [[Brent Berlin|Berlin]], Breedlove, and Raven endeavored to learn more about other systems of environment classifications and to compare them to [[Taxonomy (biology)|Western scientific taxonomies]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Prado|first=Helbert Medeiros|last2=Murrieta|first2=Rui S√©rgio Sereni|last3=Prado|first3=Helbert Medeiros|last4=Murrieta|first4=Rui S√©rgio Sereni|date=2015-12|title=ETHNOECOLOGY IN PERSPECTIVE: THE ORIGINS, INTERFACES AND CURRENT TRENDS OF A GROWING FIELD|url=http://www.scielo.br/scielo.php?script=sci_abstract&pid=S1414-753X2015000400009&lng=en&nrm=iso&tlng=en|journal=Ambiente & Sociedade|volume=18|issue=4|pages=139‚Äì160|doi=10.1590/1809-4422ASOC986V1842015|issn=1414-753X}}</ref>
==Principles==
[[Ethnoscience]] emphasizes the importance of how societies make sense of their own reality. In order to understand how cultures perceive the world around them, like the classification and organization of the environment<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://www.oxfordreference.com/view/10.1093/acref/9780199754670.001.0001/acref-9780199754670|title=The Encyclopedia of Religion and Nature|publisher=Continuum|isbn=9780199754670|language=en-US|doi=10.1093/acref/9780199754670.001.0001}}</ref>, ethnoecology borrows methods from linguistics and cultural anthropology<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.lehigh.edu/~dac511/pages/research/ethnoecol.html|title=Ethnoecology, David Casagrande|website=www.lehigh.edu|access-date=2018-11-05}}</ref>. Ethnoecology is a major part of an anthropologist‚Äôs toolkit; ¬†it helps researchers understand how the society conceptualizes their surrounding environment i and that it can determine what the society considers "worth attending to" in their ecological system.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/864107613|title=An ethnoecological approach to the study of a village Himachal Pradesh|last=Anindita.|first=Ghosh,|date=2012|publisher=LAP LAMBERT Academic Publishing|isbn=9783659305320|edition=1. Aufl|location=Saarbr√ºcken|oclc=864107613}}</ref> This information can ultimately be useful for other approaches used in [[environmental anthropology]].
Ethnoecology is a field of [[environmental anthropology]], and has derived much of its characteristics from classic as well as more modern theorists. [[Franz Boas]] was one of the first anthropologists to question [[unilineal evolution]], the belief that all societies follow the same, unavoidable path towards [[Western civilization]]. Boas strongly urged anthropologists to gather detailed ethnographic data from an [[emic]] standpoint in order to understand different cultures.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Goldman|first=Irving|date=1959|title=Evolution and Anthropology|url=http://www.jstor.org/stable/3825587|journal=Victorian Studies|volume=3|issue=1|pages=55‚Äì75}}</ref> [[Julian Steward]] was another anthropologist whose ideas and theories influenced the use of ethnoecology. Steward coined the term [[cultural ecology]], the study of human adaptations to social and physical environments, and focused on how evolutionary paths in similar societies result in different trajectories instead of the classic global trends in evolution.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://anthropology.ua.edu/cultures/cultures.php?culture=Ecological%20Anthropology|title=Ecological Anthropology - Anthropological Theories - Department of Anthropology - The University of Alabama|website=anthropology.ua.edu|access-date=2018-11-05}}</ref> This new perspective on [[cultural evolution]] was ¬†later named [[multilineal evolution]]. Both Boas and Steward believed that a researcher must use an emic standpoint and that cultural adaptation to an environment is not the same for each society. Furthermore, Steward's cultural ecology provides an important theoretical antecedent for ethnoecology.<ref name=":0" /> Another contributor to the framework of ethnoecology was anthropologist [[Leslie White]]. ¬†White emphasized the interpretation of cultures as [[System|systems]] and laid the foundations for interpreting the intersection of [[Cultural system|cultural systems]] with [[Ecosystem|ecosystems]] as well as their integration into a coherent whole. Altogether, these anthropologists, established the foundations of ethnoecology we see today.
== Traditional ecological knowledge ==
[[Traditional Ecological Knowledge]] (TEK), also known as [[Indigenous Knowledge]], "refers to the evolving knowledge acquired by indigenous and local peoples over hundreds or thousands of years through direct contact with the environment."<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.fws.gov/nativeamerican/traditional-knowledge.html|title=Fish and Wildlife Service - Native American Liaison|last=Service|first=U.S. Fish and Wildlife|website=www.fws.gov|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-05}}</ref> It involves the accumulated knowledge, beliefs, and practices widely held by a specific community through their relationship with the environment. In this context, TEK consists of a community‚Äôs shared ideas when considering subjects such as the acceptable uses of plants and animals, the best approach to maximizing the potential uses of land, the social institutions in which members of society are expected to navigate, and holistically, their [[worldview]].<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Berkes|first=Fikret|last2=Folke|first2=Mina Kislalioglu, Carl|last3=Gadgil|first3=Madhav|date=1998-09-01|title=Minireviews: Exploring the Basic Ecological Unit: Ecosystem-like Concepts in Traditional Societies|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs100219900034|journal=Ecosystems|language=en|volume=1|issue=5|pages=409‚Äì415|doi=10.1007/s100219900034|issn=1432-9840}}</ref>
The study of TEK frequently includes critiques of the theoretical division between cultural systems and ecosystems, interpreting humans as an integral part of the whole.<ref name=":1" /> Humans, for example, can represent a [[keystone species]] in a given ecosystem and can play critical roles in creating, maintaining, and sustaining it . They can contribute to processes such as [[pedogenesis]], [[seed dispersal]], and fluctuations in [[biodiversity]].<ref>{{Citation|last=Berkes|first=Fikret|title=Traditional Ecological Knowledge, Biodiversity, Resilience and Sustainability|date=1994|url=https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-94-011-1006-8_15|work=Biodiversity Conservation: Problems and Policies|pages=269‚Äì287|publisher=Springer Netherlands|language=en|doi=10.1007/978-94-011-1006-8_15|isbn=9780792331407|access-date=2018-11-05|last2=Folke|first2=Carl|last3=Gadgil|first3=Madhav}}</ref> They can also modify and condition [[Ethology|animal behavior]] in either wild or domesticated species.<ref name=":1" />
Traditional Ecological Knowledge has traditionally focused on what Western science can learn from these communities and how closely their cultural knowledge mirrors scientific structures.<ref name=":1" /> It has been argued that this previous understanding of ecological adaptation could have major influences on our ecological actions in the future.
==Local knowledge in western society==
Within the discipline of Ethnoecology, there is a clear emphasis on those societies that are deemed "[[indigenous peoples|indigenous]]," "[[traditional]]," or "[[Noble savage|savage]]," a common trend in anthropological pursuits through the 20th century.<ref name="haenn_calakmul">{{Cite journal | last = Haenn | first = Nora | year = 2000 | title = Biodiversity Is Diversity in Use: Community-Based Conservation in the Calakmul Biosphere Reserve | journal = America Verde Working Papers | volume = 7 | pages = 5 }}</ref> However, societies exist within a wide range of biomes, and have needs to know and understand clear and present dangers beyond those of harmful plants or how to get the best crop.<ref name="haenn_calakmul" /> Cruikshank contends that this may because many see Traditional Ecological Knowledge as a "static, timeless, and hermetically sealed" notion.<ref name="cruikshank_glaciers">{{Cite book|title=Do Glaciers Listen? : Local Knowledge, Colonial Encounters, and Social Imagination|last=Cruikshank|first=Julie|publisher=University of Washington Press|year=2005|location=Seattle|pages=9}} </ref> Locked within time and space, there is no opportunity to innovate, and is therefore not found within the very new structures of a [[post-industrial society]], such as that of the United States.
In this way, ethnoecologies may exist without the bounded notion of the ''other''. For example, social scientists have attempted to understand the markers inner-city youth use to identify a threat to their livelihood, including the wearing of gang colors, tattoos, or protrusions through clothes that may represent or be a weapon.<ref name="mathios_poverty">{{Cite journal | last = Mathios | first = Alan | year = 2009 | title = Exploring the Ecology of Poverty | journal = Human Ecology | volume = 37 | issue = 2 | pages = 5 | url = https://issuu.com/humec_comm/docs/vol37_no2_fall2009 | publisher = College of Human Ecology }}</ref> Likewise, concepts are spread about the health and needs of the community as they are related to the area around them. Instilled with recognizing dangers at an early age, and who these threats come from, a set of beliefs are held by the members of the society on how to live in their country, city, or neighborhood. This broadening of the discipline (bordering on [[human ecology]]) is important because it identifies the environment as not just the plants and animals, but also the humans and technologies a group of people have access to.
Similarly, social scientists have begun to use ethnoecological surveys in ethnographic studies in attempts to understand and address topics relevant in Western society as well as prevalent around the world.<ref name="mathios_poverty" /> This includes researching the ways in which people view their choices and abilities in manipulating the world around them, especially in their ability to subsist.
== Traditional Medicine == Traditional societies often treat medical issues through the utilization of their local environment. For example, in Chinese herbal medicine people consider how to utilize native plants for healing.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://nccih.nih.gov/health/whatiscam/chinesemed.htm|title=Traditional Chinese Medicine: In Depth|website=NCCIH|language=en|access-date=2018-11-05}}</ref>
Almost 80% of the world‚Äôs population utilizes ethnobotanical methods as a main source of treatment for illnesses, according to WHO.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Farnsworth|first=Norman R.|last2=Akerele|first2=Olayiwola|last3=Bingel|first3=Audrey S.|last4=Soejarto|first4=Djaja D.|last5=Guo|first5=Zhengang|date=1985|title=Medicinal plants in therapy |journal=Bulletin of the World Health Organization|volume=63|issue=6|pages=965‚Äì981 |pmc=2536466|pmid=3879679}}</ref> ¬†In the face of modern climate change, many traditional medicinal practices have been promoted for their environmental sustainability<ref>{{Cite journal|date=1995-02-01|title=Ecology and ethnomedicine: Exploring links between current environmental crisis and indigenous medical practices|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/0277953694E0098D|journal=Social Science & Medicine|language=en|volume=40|issue=3|pages=321‚Äì329|doi=10.1016/0277-9536(94)E0098-D|issn=0277-9536}}</ref>, such as Ayurveda from India.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Rastogi|first=Sanjeev|last2=Kaphle|first2=Krishna|date=2011|title=Sustainable Traditional Medicine: Taking the Inspirations from Ancient Veterinary Science|url=https://www.hindawi.com/journals/ecam/2011/151435/|journal=Evidence-Based Complementary and Alternative Medicine|language=en|volume=2011|pages=1‚Äì6|doi=10.1093/ecam/nen071|issn=1741-427X}}</ref>
See also: [[Ethnomedicine]]
==Epistemological concerns==
According to Dove and Carpenter, "environmental anthropology sits astride the [[dichotomy]] between nature and culture, a conceptual separation between categories of nature, like wilderness and parks, and those of culture, like farms and cities.".<ref name="dove_carpenter">{{Cite book | editor1-last = Dove | editor1-first = Michael R. | editor-link = Michael R. Dove | editor2-last = Carpenter | editor2-first = Carol | editor2-link = Carol Carpenter | year = 2007 | title = Environmental Anthropology: A Historical Reader (Blackwell Anthologies in Social and Cultural Anthropology) | publisher = Wiley-Blackwell | ISBN = 1-4051-1137-2 | pages = 4 }}</ref> It is inherent in this ideology that humans are a polluting factor violating a previously pristine locale.<ref name="dove_carpenter" />
This is especially relevant due to the role in which scientists have long understood how humans have worked for and against their environmental surroundings as a whole.<ref name="berkes_unit">{{Cite journal|last=Berkes|first=Fikret|year=1998|title=Exploring the Basic Ecological Unit: Ecosystem-like Concepts in Traditional Societies|journal=Ecosystems|volume=1|issue=4|pages=409‚Äì415|doi=10.1007/s100219900034}} </ref> In this way, the idea of a corresponding, but not adversarial, relationship between society and culture was once in itself baffling and defiant to the generally accepted modes of understanding in the earlier half of the twentieth century.<ref name="berkes_unit" /> As time went on, the understood dichotomy of nature and culture continued to be challenged by ethnographers such as [[Darrell A. Posey]], John Eddins, Peter Macbeth and Debbie Myers.<ref name="posey_amazonian">{{Cite journal | last = Posey | first = Darrell A. | authorlink = Darrell A. Posey | year = 1984 | title = Ethnoecology as Applied Anthropology in Amazonian Development | journal = Human Organization | volume = 43 | issue = 2 | pages = 95‚Äì107 | ref = "Posey" }}</ref> Also present in the recognition of indigenous knowledge in the intersection of Western science is the way in which it is incorporated, if at all. Dove and Carpenter contend that some anthropologists have sought to reconcile the two through a "translation," bringing the ethnological understandings and framing them in a modern dialogue.<ref name="dove_carpenter" />
In opposition to this paradigm is an attribution to the linguistic and ideological distinctiveness found in the nomenclature and epistemologies.<ref name="gragson_ethnoecology">{{Cite book | last = Gragson | first = Ted L. | year = 1999 | title = Ethnoecology: Knowledge, Resources, and Rights | publisher = University of Georgia Press | location = Athens, Georgia | pages = v-26 | ref = "Gragson" }}</ref> This alone has created a subfield, mostly in recognition of the philosophies in [[ethnotaxonomy]].<ref name="gragson_ethnoecology" /> To define ethnotaxonomy as new or different though, is inaccurate. It is simply placing a different understanding of a long-held tradition in ethnology, discovering the terms in which different peoples use to describe their world and worldviews.<ref name="gragson_ethnoecology" /> It is worth noting that those who seek to use and understand this knowledge have actively worked to both enfranchise and disenfranchise the societies in which the information was held.<ref name="haenn_conservatism">{{Cite journal | last = Haenn | first = Nora | year = 1999 | title = The Power of Environmental Knowledge: Ethnoecology and Environmental Conflicts in Mexican Conservatism | journal = Human Ecology | volume = 27 | issue = 3 | pages = 477‚Äì491 | ref = "Haenn-Bio" | doi=10.1023/a:1018731708560 }}</ref> Haenn has noted that in several instances of working with conservationists and developers, there was a concerted effort to change the ideas of environment and ecology held by the native groups to the land, while plundering any and all texts and information on the resources found there, therefore enabling a resettlement of the land and redistribution of the knowledge, favoring the outsiders.<ref name="haenn_conservatism" />

'''Ethnofiction''' is a [[neologism]] which refers to an [[ethnographic]] [[docufiction]], a blend of [[documentary]] and [[fictional film]] in the area of [[visual anthropology]]. It is a film type in which, by means of [[fictional]] [[narrative]] or creative [[imagination]], often improvising, the portrayed characters ([[Indigenous peoples|natives]]) play their own roles as members of an [[ethnic]] or social group.
[[Jean Rouch]] is considered to be the father of ethnofiction.<ref>[http://www.maitres-fous.net/glossary.html Glossary] at MAITRES_FOUS.NET</ref> An [[ethnologist]], he discovered that a filmmaker interferes with the event he registers. His camera is never a ''candid camera''.<ref>[http://mamber.filmtv.ucla.edu/HiddenCamera/types.htm Types of Cameras] ‚Äì definition at [http://www.cinema.ucla.edu/ UCLA]</ref> The behavior of the portrayed individuals, the natives, will be affected by its presence. Contrary to the principles of [[Marcel Griaule]],<ref>[http://articles.sybilamber.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&catid=10:history-of-social-and-cultural-anthropology&id=43:marcel-griaule-1898-1956 Marcel Griaule (1898 ‚Äì 1956)] ‚Äì Article by Sybil Amber</ref><ref>[http://elnil.org/Pictorializing.htm From Pictorializing to Visual Anthropology1] ‚Äì Chapter from ‚ÄúHandbook of Methods in Cultural Anthropology‚Äù</ref><ref>[http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/08949460600596558#preview From Representation to Evocation: Tracing a Progression in Jean Rouch's ‚Äò‚ÄôLes magiciens de Wanzerb√©‚Äô‚Äô, ‚Äò‚ÄôLes ma√Ætres fous‚Äô‚Äô, and ‚Äò‚ÄôJaguar‚Äô‚Äô] ‚Äì Article by Ted Nannicelli at [http://www.tandfonline.com/ Taylor & Francis Group]</ref><ref>[http://alor.univ-montp3.fr/cerce/r5/g.c.htm L'ETHNOFICTION A L'≈íUVRE Prisme et images de l'entit√© dogon] ‚Äì Article (French) by Gaetano Ciarcia at [http://alor.univ-montp3.fr Universit√© Montpellier III]</ref> his mentor, for Rouch a non-participating camera registering ‚Äúpure‚Äù events in ethnographic research (like filming a ritual without interfering with it) is a pre-concept denied by practice.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/3504425.stm Father of 'cinema verite' dies] ‚Äì BBC news</ref><ref>[http://www.indiana.edu/~wanthro/theory_pages/Rouch.htm BIOGRAPHIES: Jean Rouch] ‚Äì Article by Ben Michaels at [http://www.indiana.edu/ Indiana University]</ref><ref>[http://www.rouge.com.au/3/rouch_tribute.html A Tribute to Jean Rouch] by Paul Stoller at [http://www.rouge.com.au/ Rouge]</ref><ref>[[Ethnographic film#Origins|Ethnographic Film]] (origines)</ref><ref>[http://www.maitres-fous.net/Cooper.html Knowing Images: Jean Rouch‚Äôs Ethnography] <- Chapter from Sarah Cooper's monograph ‚ÄúSelfless Cinema?: Ethics and French Documentary‚Äù (Oxford: Legenda, 2006) at [http://www.maitres-fous.net/home.html MAITRES-FOUS.net]</ref>
An ethnographer cameraperson, in this view, will be accepted as a natural partner by the actors who play their roles. The cameraperson will be one of them, and may even be possessed by the [[rhythm]] of dancers during a ritual celebration and induced in a state of ''cine-[[trance]]''.<ref>[http://www.cinetrance.com/cine-trance.htm Cine-trance]</ref><ref>[http://der.org/jean-rouch/pdf/American_Anthropologist_Tribute.pdf Cine-trance: a Tribute to Jean Rouch](Visual Anthropology, American Anthropologist)</ref> Going further than his predecessors, [[Jean Rouch]] introduces the [[actor]] as a tool in research.
A new genre was born.<ref>Jean Rouch and the Genesis of Ethnofiction ‚Äì thesis by Brian Quist (Long Island University)</ref> [[Robert Flaherty]], a main reference for Rouch, may be seen as the grandfather of this [[genre]], although he was a pure documentary maker and not an ethnographer.
Being mainly used to refer to [[ethnographic]] films as an object of visual anthropology, the term ethnofiction is as well adequate to refer to experimental documentaries preceding and following Rouch's oeuvre and to any [[fictional]] creation in human communication, arts or literature, having an ethnographical or social background.
==History== Parallel to those of Flaherty or Rouch, ethnic portraits of hard local realities are often drawn in Portuguese films since the thirties, with particular incidence from the sixties to the eighties,<ref>[http://www.comite-film-ethno.net/colloque-2006/pdf/constructions-identitaires/alves-costa.pdf Imagining Rurality: Portuguese Documentary and Ethnographic Film in the 1960s and 1990s] ‚Äì Abstract for a conference by Catarina Alves Costa at [http://www.comite-film-ethno.net/ Comit√© du Film Ethnographique]</ref> and again in the early 21st century. The remote Tr√°s-os-Montes region (see: [[Tr√°s-os-Montes e Alto Douro Province]] in [[Portugal]]), [[Guin√©e Bissau]] or the [[Cape Vert]] islands (ancient Portuguese colonies), which step in the limelights from the eighties on thanks to the work of certain directors ([[Flora Gomes]], [[Pedro Costa]], or [[Daniel E. Thorbecke]], the unknown author of [[Terra Longe]] <ref>[http://woyingi.wordpress.com/2011/04/02/african-filmmaker-profiles-flora-gomes/ African Filmmaker Profiles: Flora Gomes] at [http://woyingi.wordpress.com/ The Woyingi Blog]</ref><ref>[http://reehanmiah.wordpress.com/2010/12/27/pedrocosta/ The Films of Pedro Costa] at [http://reehanmiah.wordpress.com/ Distant Voices]</ref><ref>[http://www.spla.pro/fiche.php?no=1094&type=films Terra Longe] at [http://www.spla.pro/ South Planet] (French)</ref>) are themes for pioneering films of this genre, important landmarks in film history. Arousing fiction in the heart of [[ethnicity]] is something current in the Portuguese popular narrative ([[oral literature]]): in other words, the traditional attraction for [[legend]] and [[surrealistic]] imagery in popular arts<ref>[http://d1113048.dotsterhost.com/The_Portuguese_and_the_others.pdf The Portuguese and the ‚Äúothers‚Äù: dialogue of cultures and characters in oral literary tradition] - Article by Maria Edite Orange and Maria In√™s Pinho at Departamento de Artes e Motricidade Humana do IPP ‚Äì Escola Superior de Educa√ß√£o (Porto)</ref> inspires certain Portuguese films to strip off realistic predicates and become poetical fiction. This practice is common to many fictional films by [[Manoel de Oliveira]] and [[Jo√£o C√©sar Monteiro]] and to several [[docufiction]] hybrids by [[Ant√≥nio Campos]], [[Ant√≥nio Reis]] and [[Ricardo Costa (filmmaker)|Ricardo Costa]].<ref>[http://www.scielo.oces.mctes.pt/pdf/etn/v14n3/v14n3a05.pdf Things we see: Portuguese anthropology on material culture] ‚Äì Paper by Filomena Silvano at [http://www.scielo.oces.mctes.pt/ Scielo]</ref><ref>[http://www.movingimagesource.us/articles/disquieting-objects-20110503 Disquieting Objects] - Article by Gabe Klinger at [http://www.movingimagesource.us/ The Museum of Moving Image]</ref><ref>[http://d1113048.dotsterhost.com/RCen.pdf Ricardo Costa and the Flowing Pictures] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110710145733/http://d1113048.dotsterhost.com/RCen.pdf |date=July 10, 2011 }} ‚Äì Article by [[Jos√© de Matos-Cruz]]</ref> Since the 1960s, ethnofiction (local real life and fantasy in one) is a distinctive mark of Portuguese cinema.
==Chronology==
===1920s===
* 1926 ‚Äì ''[[Moana (1926 film)|Moana]]'' by [[Robert Flaherty]], EUA
===1930s===
* 1930 ‚Äì ''[[Maria do Mar]]'' by [[Jos√© Leit√£o de Barros]], [[Portugal]] * 1931 ‚Äì ''[[Tabu (1931 film)|Tabu]]'' written by [[Robert Flaherty]] and directed by [[F. W. Murnau]], USA * 1932 ‚Äì ''L'or des mers'' by [[Jean Epstein]], [[France]] * 1933 ‚Äì ''[[Las Hurdes: Tierra Sin Pan]]'' by [[Luis Bu√±uel]], [[Spain]] * 1934 ‚Äì ''[[Man of Aran]]'' by [[Robert Flaherty]], UK
===1940s===
* 1942 ‚Äì ''[[Ala-Arriba! (film)|Ala-Arriba!]]'' by [[Jos√© Leit√£o de Barros]]. [[Portugal]] * 1948 ‚Äì ''[[Louisiana Story]]'' by [[Robert Flaherty]] EUA
===1950s=== * 1955 - ''[[Les ma√Ætres fous]]'' (The Mad Masters) by [[Jean Rouch]]. [[France]] * 1958 ‚Äì ''[[Moi, un noir]]'' (Me a Black) by Jean Rouch. France
===1960s===
* 1961 ‚Äì ''La pyramide humaine'' by [[Jean Rouch]], [[France]] * 1962 ‚Äì ''Acto da Primavera'' (Act of Spring) by [[Manoel de Oliveira]]. [[Portugal]] * 1963 ‚Äì ''[[Pour la suite du monde]]'' (Of Whales, the Moon and Men) by [[Pierre Perrault]] and [[Michel Brault]], [[Canada]] * 1967 - ''Jaguar'', by [[Jean Rouch]], [[France]]
===1970s===
* 1976 ‚Äì ''[[People from Praia da Vieira]]'' (Gente da Praia da Vieira) by [[Ant√≥nio Campos]], [[Portugal]] * 1976 ‚Äì ''[[Changing Tides]]'' (Mau Tempo, Mar√©s e Mudan√ßa) by [[Ricardo Costa (filmmaker)|Ricardo Costa]], [[Portugal]] * 1976 ‚Äì ''[[Tr√°s-os-Montes (film)|Tr√°s-os-Montes]]'' by [[Ant√≥nio Reis]] and [[Margarida Cordeiro]], [[Portugal]] * 1979 ‚Äì ''[[Bread and Wine (film)|Bread and Wine]]'' (O P√£o e o Vinho) by [[Ricardo Costa (filmmaker)|Ricardo Costa]], [[Portugal]]

* 1988 ‚Äì ''[[Mortu Nega]]'' (Death Denied) by [[Flora Gomes]], [[Guin√©-Bissau]]

* 2000 ‚Äì ''[[No Quarto da Vanda]]'' (In Vanda's Room) by [[Pedro Costa]] * 2003 ‚Äì ''[[Terra Longe]]'' (Remote Land) by [[Daniel E. Thorbecke]] * 2006 ‚Äì ''[[Colossal Youth (film)|Colossal Youth]]'' by [[Pedro Costa]] * 2007 ‚Äì ''Transfiction'' by [[Johannes Sj√∂berg]] * 2011 - ''[[Toomelah (film)|Toomelah]]'' by [[Ivan Sen]]

'''Fan-funded music''' is a type of [[crowdfunding]] that specifically pertains to [[music]].[https://www.wired.com/listening_post/2008/03/review-slicethe/ Eliot Van Buskirk, "SlicethePie Unleashes Its First Fan-Funded Album", Wired, 10 March 2008] Often, fan-funded music occurs in conjunction with direct-to-fan marketing.Chaney, D. (2010). What future for fan-funded labels in the music recording industry? The cases of MyMajorCompany and ArtistShare. International Journal of Arts Management, 12(2), 44-48. Fans of music have the option to donate and collectively raise money with the goal of jump-starting the career of a given musical artist. The fan-funding of music occurs primarily through web-based services using a [[Comparison of crowd funding services#Crowdfunding models|business model for crowdfunding]]. Fans are typically given rewards based on their monetary contributions. ==Notable platforms== {| style="width:50%; text-align: center;" class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Website !! Year
of
Launch !! Notes |- | [[ArtistShare|ArtistShare.com]] ||2000 || First crowdfunding site for music |- | [[Indiegogo|Indiegogo.com]] ||2008||Disburses funds immediately |- | [[Kickstarter|Kickstarter.com]] || 2009|| Takes 5% flat fee, Stripe takes additional 3-5% |- | [[Patreon|Patreon.com]] || 2013 || Enables fans to support and engage with artists and creators |- | [[PledgeMusic|Pledgemusic.com]] || 2009 ||Can donate profits to charity. International. |- | [[Rocket Fuel|Rocketfuelhq.com]] || 2014 || Takes 5-10%. Based in UK. |- | [[RocketHub|Rockethub.com]] || 2010 || Takes 8% total funds accumulated. No screening process. |- | [[Sellaband|Sellaband.com]] ||2006 || Currency in [[‚Ç¨]]. Partners with [[Soundcloud]]. |} ===Additional information=== '''[[ArtistShare|ArtistShare.com]]'''
ArtistShare is documented as being the first fan-funded website for music.[http://knowledge.wharton.upenn.edu/article.cfm?articleid=2647 ‚ÄúCan You Spare a Quarter? Crowdfunding Sites Turn Fans into Patrons of the Arts‚Äù]. Wharton Innovation and Entrepreneurship. December 8, 2010. Retrieved November 20, 2012. The service lets musicians fund their projects utilizing a "fan-funding" model. In exchange for funding on a particular project, contributors receive various benefits. ArtistShare emphasizes on their website that for each project, the artist is in no way required to relinquish ownership of copyright, as this model is not a [[Work for hire|work made for hire]].[https://www.artistshare.com/v4/Home/About ArtistShare -- About Us]. Retrieved on November 20, 2012. '''[[Indiegogo|Indiegogo.com]]'''
Indiegogo is a [[Crowd funding]] portal that allows users to create a page for their funding campaign, set up an account with [[PayPal]], make a list of "perks" for different levels of donation, then create a [[social media]]-based publicity effort. Users publicize the projects themselves through [[Facebook]], [[Twitter]] and similar platforms. The site takes a 4% fee for successful campaigns. For campaigns that fail to raise their target amount, users have the option of either refunding all money to their contributors at no charge or keeping all money raised minus a 9% fee.{{cite web |url= http://www.indiegogo.com/learn/pricing |title= Learn More |publisher= Indiegogo |accessdate= 2012-06-16}} Unlike similar sites such as [[Kickstarter]], Indiegogo disburses the funds immediately, when the contributions are collected through the user's PayPal accounts. Indiegogo also offers direct credit card payment acceptance through their own portal. Those funds are disbursed up to two weeks after the conclusion of a campaign.{{cite news | first = Sarah | last = Needleman | title = When 'Friending' Becomes a Source of Start-Up Funds | date = November 1, 2011 | url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970204528204577007781568296346?mod=googlenews_wsj | work = Wall Street Journal | accessdate = 2011-12-05}} '''[[Kickstarter|Kickstarter.com]]'''
Often hailed as the most successful and well-known [[Crowd funding]] platform. Kickstarter has been featured on [[CNN]], [[NYT|The New York Times]], [[TIME|TIME magazine]], [[BBC]] and [[WIRED|Wired Magazine]]. Kickstarter is a [[Crowd funding]] website that has successfully funded everything from films, games, and music to art, design, and technology. Project creators choose a deadline and a goal minimum of funds to raise. If the chosen goal is not gathered by the deadline, no funds are collected. The platform is open to backers from anywhere in the world and to creators from the US or the UK. Kickstarter takes a 5% fee and [[Amazon.com]] takes an additional 3%. '''[[PledgeMusic|PledgeMusic.com]]'''
PledgeMusic is an international [[Crowd funding]] platform geared specifically toward musicians. Users (Pledgers) receive exclusive content in exchange for their contributions to artists fundraising campaigns. PledgeMusic does not retain any ownership or rights to any music created through the platform. Funding transactions occur only after a goal is successfully met. The site is staffed my music industry moguls and maintains partnerships with major players in the digital and physical music spheres allowing for numerous options to help record, produce, manufacture, market, and distribute artist's music, merchandise, and tickets. The site charges a 15% flat fee.[http://www.pledgemusic.com/site/about PledgeMusic.com -- about]. Retrieved November 27, 2012. PledgeMusic operates on two types of artist campaigns, [[direct-to-fan]] and a Pre-order campaign. In a pre-order campaign, fans are charged immediately upon pledging. This type of campaign is designed for labels and artists who have already completed a recording, and are looking for a strategic way to pre-sell and market it.[http://www.pledgemusic.com/site/faq PledgeMusic.com -- FAQ]. Retrieved November 26, 2012. '''[[RocketHub|RocketHub.com]]'''
Rocket Hub is an established [[crowd funding]] platform open to anyone including musicians. Project holders on Rocket Hub have the option to keep raised proceeds even if the fundraising pledge was not successful. Rocket Hub is a completely open platform, meaning that anyone can create a fan-funding campaign and there is no screening process before the project goes live. The site takes an 8% commission off successful projects.[http://www.musicthinktank.com/blog/the-musicians-guide-to-fan-funding.html Ostrow, Jonathan -- Musician's guide to Fan-Funded Music -- August 16th, 2010]. Retrieved November 27th, 2012. '''[[Sellaband|Sellaband.com]]'''
Sellaband is a [[crowd funding]] platform that allows registered Artists to use a [[direct-to-fan]] approach to finance albums or concerts.[https://www.sellaband.com/en/pages/how_it_works_artists Sellaband.com -- How it Works -- Artists.] Retrieved November 27, 2012. Artists will pledge an amount, the minimum funding target being [[‚Ç¨]] 3000, and the maximum funding target, ‚Ç¨250.000. Artists may also choose if they want to integrate a [[revenue sharing]] option into their funding. The minimum incentive is a download.{{cite web|url=https://www.sellaband.com/believer/new#artist|title=Sellaband - Join SellaBand|author=SellaBand|work=SellaBand}} ==Cases of note== ===Marillion=== The British rock band [[Marillion]] are considered to be one of the first artists to have truly harnessed the power of the [[internet]] as a means of music distribution and direct contact with fans, which began with setting up a website in 1996 and raising $60,000 to help finance a 1997 North American tour.{{cite news | url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/music/1325340.stm | title= Marillion fans to the rescue | first=Tim |last=Masters | work=BBC News | date=2001-05-11}} They have also been described by ''[[The Guardian]]'' music journalist [[Alexis Petridis]] as "the undisputed pioneers" of the fan-funded music model,{{cite news | url= https://www.theguardian.com/music/2008/apr/18/popandrock.alexispetridis | title= This song was brought to you by ... | work=The Guardian | first=Alexis | last=Petridis | date=18 April 2008 | accessdate=16 June 2015}} beginning with the distribution of their 2001 release ''[[Anoraknophobia]]''. Amidst a dissolving relationship with their record label and management team, the band calculated that they would need 5,000 fans to order the album to finance the project. However, they needed the money up-front, before the record was released. They turned to their mailing list and asked fans to pre-order the album in what was later described by the [[BBC]] as "a unique funding campaign". Pre-sales well exceeded their 5,000-unit target (reaching about 12,000 pre-sales total).[http://www.music4point5.com/blog/the-marillion-story-and-what-we-can-all-learn-from-it/ The Marillion story and what we can all learn from it - Music 4.5] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121109142548/http://www.music4point5.com/blog/the-marillion-story-and-what-we-can-all-learn-from-it/ |date=2012-11-09 }} Marillion have since released several other albums based on a fan-funded model, receiving a ¬£360,000 advance for their 15th studio album ''[[Happiness Is the Road]]''. ===Amanda Palmer=== Unofficially dubbed the "queen" of Kickstarter, [[Amanda Palmer]] is an example of one of the most successful fan-funded music campaigns of all time. On April 30, 2012, Palmer ran a campaign on Kickstarter, with a goal of $100,000 to fund her newest studio album, ''[[Theatre Is Evil]]''. By the end of May 2012, Palmer had amassed almost $1.2 million, ultimately receiving donations from nearly 25,000 individuals.{{cite web|url=http://www.kickstarter.com/projects/amandapalmer/amanda-palmer-the-new-record-art-book-and-tour|title=Amanda Palmer: The new RECORD, ART BOOK, and TOUR|work=Kickstarter}} By comparison, the average successful project on Kickstarter at the time raised about $5,000.{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/06/arts/music/amanda-palmer-takes-connecting-with-her-fans-to-a-new-level.html | work=The New York Times | first=Ben | last=Sisario | title=Amanda Palmer Takes Connecting With Her Fans to a New Level | date=June 5, 2012}} ===Ellis Paul=== Boston-based singer/songwriter [[Ellis Paul]] is another important case study in the field of fan-funded music. His 2010 release, The Day After Everything Changed, was funded completely by fan donations. Instead of using a traditional crowd-funding platform, he adapted the online merchandise platform [[Nimbit]] to his own fan-funding scheme. Paul set up a tiered donation hierarchy, ranging from the $15 Street Busker level, up to the $10,000 Woody Guthrie level.{{cite web|url=http://ellispaul.com/index.php?page=news&display=2339|title=ELLIS PAUL|date=9 July 2008|work=Ellis Paul}} Fans received different perks based on the tier at which they donated. The project proved to be highly successful, with total donations exceeding $100,000.{{cite web|url=http://www.boston.com/ae/music/articles/2009/04/12/lighters_down_checkbooks_up/|title=Musicians and fans join together to get albums made - The Boston Globe|work=boston.com}} Paul is putting his fan-funding to the test again; he is currently in the midst of fan-funding a new studio album set to release sometime in 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.ellispaul.com/index.php?page=blog&category=&display=5695|title=ELLIS PAUL|date=26 September 2012|work=Ellis Paul}} ===Electric Eel Shock=== [[Tokyo]]-based [[garage rock|garage]] [[heavy metal music|metal]] band [[Electric Eel Shock]] is another group that has seen some success in the way of fan-funded music. In 2004 they offered a "SAMURAI 100" package, which gave fans the opportunity to secure "guest list for life" status. The package cost ¬£100 and the band raised ¬£10,000 by selling 100 such packages.{{cite web|url=http://drownedinsound.com/news/10764-wanna-go-vip-electric-eel-shock-ll-show-you-the-way|title=Wanna Go VIP? Electric Eel Shock'll show you the way...|work=DrownedInSound}} ==Criticism== As a business practice, fan-funded music is not without its criticism. Fan-funded music has gained popularity in the past few years however, money raised through these platforms still is only estimated to make up 1% of the amount spent on albums and tours. Many bands start off with fan funding to finance their initial album but then get signed to a record label. Major labels are signing artists with successful fan funded campaigns using the campaigns as a filter before investing in them.{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2010/jan/21/fan-funded-model-record-deal | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Helienne | last=Lindvall | title=Behind the music: The fan-funded model that led to a major record deal | date=January 21, 2010}} Other, more well-known bands have used fan funding to distance themselves from their label contracts and manage their own music. There has yet to be a band that has used fan funding to fully finance their career.{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-18788054 | work=BBC News | title=How fan-funding is changing the face of music finance | date=July 12, 2012}} In 2001, ''The Guardian'' journalist [[Gareth McLean]] was scathing of Marillion's pioneering efforts to continue their career without a label by dealing directly with their fans on the Internet, writing: "They have, they explained, decided to eschew the machinations of the record industry in order to be closer to the people. (One suspects that their decision occurred round about the time that the record industry decided to shun Marillion)."{{cite web | url= https://www.theguardian.com/media/2001/aug/13/tvandradio.television1 | title= In the realm of pretences| author=Gareth McLean| date=13 August 2001|work=The Guardian |location=UK}} Some claim that artists overestimate the cost of recording an album and dishonestly solicit more money than they need via fan-funding.{{cite web|url=http://www.musicthinktank.com/blog/an-argument-against-fan-funding.html|title=An Argument Against Fan Funding - MTT - Music Think Tank|work=musicthinktank.com}} With advancements in digital technology, recording equipment has become increasingly compact and more affordable. It is no longer a requirement for an artist to need a large recording studio that houses oversized equipment. This increase in accessibility that the everyday musician has today has made it possible for artists to record their own albums from their homes. Since there are no restrictions for what artists can ask for, it is not unheard of for artists to inflate the expected costs and then keep the extra money as profit. Critics also point out that the fan-funded music model has turned bands into marketers and sales personnel. Artists must be able to develop personal marketing strategies in order to get the money to even begin working on their music.{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/blog/index.php?blog=10&title=the_problem_with_fan_funded_music&more=1&c=1&tb=1&pb=1|title=The Problem With Fan-Funded Music|author=NME.COM|work=nme.com}} Artists must put lots of time and effort into creating a campaign that engages their fans and gets them to donate to their project. This can prove difficult for any artist to create a campaign that does not come off as "[a] shrill and desperate-modern-day pan-handling by entitled go-getters."{{citation needed|date=February 2015}} While fan-funded platforms are accessible for any musician, they have become over-crowded with both artists and anyone with an idea. "For every legitimately exciting pitch there are dozens of musicians, filmmakers and designers pleading for funds to complete ill-conceived projects."{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10000872396390443991704577579190431157610|title=The Good, the Bad and the Crowdfunded|author=Erik Sofge|date=18 August 2012|work=WSJ}} Running fan-funded campaigns cost bands a large sum of money. They must pay for video production for the video that every campaign has,{{citation needed|date=December 2012}} a producer and an engineer to mix and master their album, and fulfill all of the rewards promised to their fans as well as the shipping on them. Often the money made off these projects ends up going to paying the costs of running a successful fan funded campaign. For example, a large portion of the $1 million that [[Amanda Palmer]] raised went into funding her [[Kickstarter]] project itself.{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/therecord/2012/11/23/165658174/how-much-does-crowdfunding-cost-musicians|title=How Much Does Crowd Funding Cost Musicians?|date=23 November 2012|work=NPR.org}} Artists such as Palmer have huge fan bases to appeal to for money, but for the average artist raising that kind of money isn't a reliable method.{{cite web|url=http://www.musicclout.com/contents/article-116-why-i-hate-crowd-funding-by-normandie-wilson.aspx|title=Music Clout|work=musicclout.com}} ==See also== * [[Crowd funding]] * [[Comparison of crowd funding services]] * [[Direct-to-fan]] * [[Freemium]] * [[Free-to-play]] * [[Kickstarter]] * [[Open Music Model]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} [[Category:Music industry]] [[Category:Crowdfunding]]
